{{distinguish|Black (singer)}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = 6lack | background = solo_singer | image = 6lack 2018.png | caption = 6lack in 2018 | birth_name = Ricardo Valdez Valentine | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1992|6|24}} | birth_place = [[Baltimore, Maryland]], U.S. | origin = [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], U.S. | genre = {{hlist|[[Contemporary R&B|R&B]]|[[Trap music|trap]]|[[alternative R&B]]|[[Hip hop music|hip hop]]}} | occupation = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter|rapper}} | instrument = Vocals | years_active = 2011–present | label = {{hlist|LoveRenaissance|[[Interscope Records|Interscope]]}} | associated_acts = [[Spillage Village]] <!-- only artists within criteria of [[Template:Infobox musical artist#associated acts]] --> | website = {{URL|6lack.com}} }}
'''Ricardo Valdez Valentine''' (born June 24, 1992), better known by his [[stage name]] '''6lack''' (stylized as '''6LACK'''; pronounced "black"), is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper from [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]].<ref name="Genius">{{cite web|url=https://genius.com/a/meet-6lack-the-atlanta-artist-whose-song-prblms-is-destined-to-be-a-hit|title=Meet Rising Atlanta Artist: 6LACK|publisher=Genius|accessdate=November 17, 2016}}</ref>
He initially gained notable recognition following the release of his single, "[[Prblms]]", taken from his debut album, ''[[Free 6lack]]'', which was released in November 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pigeonsandplanes.com/discover/2016/06/daily-discovery-6lack|title=Daily Discovery: 6LACK|publisher=Pigeons and Planes|accessdate=November 17, 2016}}</ref> He released his second album, ''[[East Atlanta Love Letter]]'' in September 2018, which peaked at number three on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] chart. 6lack is currently signed to LoveRenaissance and [[Interscope Records]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefader.com/2016/11/17/6lack-interview-rules|title=Meet 6LACK|publisher=Fader|accessdate=November 18, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://djbooth.net/news/entry/2016-10-17-meet-6lack|title=LoveRenaissance's New R&B Star In The Making|publisher=DJ Booth|accessdate=November 18, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/7548366/6lack/biography|title=6LACK - Biography|publisher=Billboard|accessdate=November 27, 2016}}</ref> He is also a member of the Atlanta-Baltimore music collective [[Spillage Village]], founded by [[EarthGang]] and [[J.I.D]].
==Early life== Valentine was born on June 24, 1992 in [[Baltimore, Maryland]] and moved to [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] with his parents in 1997.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/7573628/6lack-free-debut-album-interview|title=6lack Talks Industry Growing Pains, Love Songs & Moody Debut Album 'Free 6lack'|publisher=Billboard|accessdate=November 18, 2016}}</ref> He is the oldest of 3 siblings. Valentine's first [[Sound recording and reproduction|recording]] experience was when he was 4 years of age, at his father's studio.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hotnewhiphop.com/everything-you-need-to-know-about-6lack-news.27901.html|title=Everything You Need To Know About 6LACK|publisher=}}</ref> He began rapping in middle school as a [[battle rapper]] and was involved in many battles in his youth including against rapper [[Young Thug]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.gq.com/story/6lack-interview-breakout-atlanta-rapper-singer|title=How 6lack Went From Sleeping in a Recording Studio to Touring with The Weeknd|last=Schmelling|first=Clay Skipper,Michael|date=2017-03-30|work=GQ|access-date=2017-09-18|language=en}}</ref>
==Career== ===2011–2017: Beginnings and ''Free 6lack''=== [[File:6LACK.jpg|180px|left|thumbnail|6lack in January 2017.]] 6lack signed a [[record deal]] with [[Flo Rida]]'s International Music Group and Strong Arm Records in July 2011. He left [[Valdosta State University]] once he signed, and spent the next few years learning about the industry. 6lack spent five years with the label, putting music out on his [[SoundCloud]] account. 6lack had little financial security and spent most of his time sleeping in the studio or outside on the street after moving to [[Miami]] to work on music with the record label.<ref name=":0" /> 6lack eventually left his label due to issues over artistic license and management.<ref name="auto">{{Cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/7573628/6lack-free-debut-album-interview|title=6lack Talks Industry Growing Pains, Love Songs & Moody Debut Album 'Free 6lack'|work=Billboard|access-date=2017-09-18}}</ref> In 2015, 6lack announced that he had joined the musical collective [[Spillage Village]] after living with the members of [[EarthGang]], and appeared on four tracks of Spillage Village EP called ''Bears Like This Too'' in 2015.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Kramer |first1=Kyle |title=This New Spillage Village EP Is About to Trigger a Worldwide Weed Shortage |url=https://noisey.vice.com/en_ca/article/64yabw/spillage-village-bears-like-this-too-ep-premiere |website=Noisey Vice}}</ref>
[[File:6lack August 2017.jpg|180px|right|thumbnail|6lack performing in August 2017.]] Once he left the label, he signed with a label LoveRenaissance and [[Interscope Records]].<ref name="Genius" /> In November 2016, ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' included 6lack in their list of "10 New Artists You Need to Know".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/10-new-artists-you-need-to-know-november-2016-w449519/6lack-w449628|title=10 New Artists You Need to Know: November 2016|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=November 17, 2016|accessdate=November 14, 2017}}</ref> He then went on to release his debut studio album, ''[[Free 6lack]]'', which peaked at number 34 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] chart.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/music/6lack/chart-history/billboard-200|title=6LACK Chart History: Billboard 200|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=September 22, 2018}}</ref> The album's single "[[Prblms]]" peaked at number 73 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] chart and became his first platinum record.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/6lack-sells-1-million-records-for-prblms-news.34761.html?|title=6lack Sells 1 Million Records For "Prblms"|last=K. Q.|first=Q.|date=July 8, 2017|publisher=Urbanlinx Media|language=English|accessdate=17 July 2017}}</ref> In April 2017, he joined Canadian singer [[The Weeknd]] as opening act for his [[Starboy: Legend of the Fall Tour|Legend of the Fall]] tour in North America.
===2018–present: ''East Atlanta Love Letter''=== In April 2018, he released the single "[[OTW (Khalid, Ty Dolla Sign and 6lack song)|OTW]]" with [[Khalid (singer)|Khalid]] and [[Ty Dolla Sign]], which has reached at number 57 on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/6lack/chart-history/hot-100|title=6LACK Chart History: Billboard Hot 100|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=May 1, 2018}}</ref> The first [[single (music)|single]] for his sophomore album, "Switch", was released on June 22, 2018 with a music video released on July 16.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hussein |first1=Wandera |title=6LACK crashes and burns in the “Switch” music video |url=http://www.thefader.com/2018/07/16/6lack-switch-music-video |website=The FADER |accessdate=14 September 2018 |language=en}}</ref> "Nonchalant" was released as the album's second single on August 17, with its accompanying music video.<ref name="NonchalantHypebeast">{{cite web |last1=Montes |first1=Patrick |title=6LACK Drops New 'East Atlanta Love Letter' Single "Nonchalant" |url=https://hypebeast.com/2018/8/6lack-nonchalant-single-stream |website=HYPEBEAST |accessdate=14 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Ch |first1=Devin |title=6LACK's "Nonchalant" Video Is A Peaceful Refrain |url=https://www.hotnewhiphop.com/6lacks-nonchalant-video-is-a-peaceful-refrain-new-video.44280.html |website=HotNewHipHop |accessdate=14 September 2018}}</ref> On September 14, 2018, 6lack released his second studio album, ''[[East Atlanta Love Letter]]'', featuring [[guest appearance]]s from [[Future (rapper)|Future]], [[J. Cole]], [[Offset (rapper)|Offset]] and Khalid. The album's release was preceded by the singles "Switch" and "Nonchalant."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2018/08/6lack-east-atlanta-love-letter-cover-art-release-date/|title=6lack 'East Atlanta Love Letter' Cover Art and Release Date|work=XXL|date=August 29, 2018|accessdate=September 3, 2018}}</ref> In October 2018, 6lack started a tour for the promotion of the album, with opening acts [[THEY.]], [[Tierra Whack]], [[Boogie (rapper)|Boogie]], Deante' Hitchcock, and Summer Walker.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hotnewhiphop.com/6lack-announces-world-tour-featuring-tierra-whack-boogie-and-more-news.57301.html |title=6LACK Announces World Tour Featuring Tierra Whack, Boogie & More |work=HotNewHipHop |date=14 August 2018|accessdate=September 3, 2018}}</ref><ref>https://www.eventbrite.ca/e/6lack-presents-from-east-atlanta-with-love-tour-with-guests-summer-walker-and-deante-hitchcock-tickets-48898288096</ref>
== Artistry == 6lack's music focuses or is based on personal and business relationships frequently, especially the topic of heartbreak.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://noisey.vice.com/en_uk/article/pgzykn/atlantas-6lack-wants-to-talk-about-real-life|title=Atlanta’s 6LACK Wants to Talk About Real Life|website=Noisey|language=en-uk|access-date=2017-09-18}}</ref> 6lack has said that his songwriting is influenced mainly by his personal experiences and failed relationships.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.highsnobiety.com/2017/04/24/6lack-prblms-interview/|title=6lack Illustrated: The Brooding Newcomer Finally Lives in Color|date=2017-09-18|work=Highsnobiety|access-date=2017-09-18|language=en-US}}</ref> ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' has described 6lack's music as "moody hip hop" that "spotlights vulnerability and honesty in a way the emoji generation can understand."<ref name="auto"/> 6lack has cited [[Sade (singer)|Sade]], [[T-Pain]], [[The-Dream]] and [[Usher (musician)|Usher]] as his influences.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.complex.com/music/2017/01/6lack-complex-interview-talks-new-music-past-and-more|title=How 6LACK Went From Atlanta Battle Rapper To Budding Superstar|work=Complex|date=January 24, 2017|accessdate=June 23, 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== In February 2017, 6lack announced the birth of his daughter, Syx Rose Valentine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/6lack-announces-birth-of-his-daughter-news.29229.html?|title=6LACK Announces Birth Of His Daughter|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=22 February 2017}}</ref>

[[File:Alaric II 484 507 gold 1470mg reverse.jpg|thumb|Reverse of a coin issued by Alaric II, gold 1.47 g. Note that the coin-portrait is actually of the Eastern Roman Emperor [[Anastasius I (emperor)|Anastasius I]]]]
'''Alaric II''' ({{lang-got|*Alareiks}}, "ruler of all";<ref>Kelsie B. Harder, ''Names and their varieties: a collection of essays in onomastics'', American Name Society, University Press of America, 1984, pp. 10-11</ref> {{circa|458/466}}{{snd}}August 507), also known as '''Alarik''', '''Alarich''', and '''Alarico''' in [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] or '''Alaricus''' in [[Latin]] — succeeded his father [[Euric]] as king of the [[Visigoths]] in [[Toulouse]] on December 28, 484; he was the great-grandson of the more famous [[Alaric I]], who sacked Rome in 410.<ref>Herwig Wolfram, ''History of the Goths'', translated by Thomas J. Dunlap (Berkeley: University of California, 1988), p. 190.</ref> He established his capital at [[Aire-sur-l'Adour]] (''Vicus Julii'') in [[Aquitaine]]. His dominions included not only the majority of [[Hispania]] (excluding its northwestern corner) but also [[Gallia Aquitania]] and the greater part of an as-yet undivided [[Gallia Narbonensis]].
==Reign== [[Herwig Wolfram]] opens his chapter on the eighth Visigothic king, "Alaric's reign gets no full treatment in the sources, and the little they do contain is overshadowed by his death in the [[Battle of Vouillé]] and the downfall of the Toulosan kingdom."<ref name=Wolfram-191>Wolfram, ''History of the Goths'', p. 191</ref> One example is [[Isidore of Seville]]'s account of Alaric's reign: consisting of a single paragraph, it is primarily about Alaric's death in that battle.<ref>Isidore of Seville, ''Historia de regibus Gothorum, Vandalorum et Suevorum'', chapter 36. Translation by Guido Donini and Gordon B. Ford, ''Isidore of Seville's History of the Goths, Vandals, and Suevi'', second revised edition (Leiden: E. J. Brill, 1970), pp. 17f</ref>
The earliest documented event in Alaric's reign concerned providing refuge to [[Syagrius]], the former ruler of the [[Domain of Soissons]] (in what is now northwestern [[France]]) who had been defeated by [[Clovis I]], King of the Franks. According to [[Gregory of Tours]]' account, Alaric was intimidated by Clovis into surrendering Syagrius to Clovis; Gregory then adds that "the Goths are a timorous race." The [[Franks]] then imprisoned Syagrius, and once his control over Syagrius' former kingdom was secure, Clovis had him beheaded.<ref name=Gregory-27>Gregory of Tours, ''Decem Libri Historiarum'', II.27; translated by Lewis Thorpe, ''History of the Franks'' (Harmondsworth: Penguin, 1974), p. 139</ref> However, Wolfram points out that at the time "Clovis got no farther than the Seine; only after several more years did the Franks succeed in occupying the rest of the Gallo-Roman buffer state north of the [[Loire]]." Any threat of war Clovis could make would only be effective if they were neighbors; "it is nowhere written that Syagrius was handed over in 486 or 487."<ref name=Wolfram-191/>
[[File:Alarico II.jpg|right|thumb|An artist's imagining of Alaric II in an illustration at the [[Biblioteca Nacional de España]]]]
Despite Frankish advances in the years that followed, Alaric was not afraid to take the military initiative when it presented itself. In 490, Alaric assisted his fellow Gothic king, [[Theodoric the Great]], in his conquest of [[Italy]] by dispatching an army to raise [[Odoacer]]'s siege of [[Pavia]], where Theodoric had been trapped.<ref>Wolfram, ''History of the Goths'', pp. 281f</ref> Then when the Franks attacked the [[Burgundians]] in the decade after 500, Alaric assisted the ruling house, and according to Wolfram the victorious Burgundian king [[Gundobad]] ceded [[Avignon]] to Alaric.<ref>Wolfram, ''History of the Goths'', p. 291</ref> By 502 Clovis and Alaric met on an island in the Loire near [[Amboise]] for face-to-face talks, which led to a peace treaty.
In 506, the [[Visigoths]] captured the city of [[Dertosa]] in the [[Ebro valley]]. There they captured the [[Roman usurper]] [[Peter (usurper)|Peter]] and had him executed.<ref>Collins, Roger. ''Visigothic Spain, 409–711''. Oxford: Blackwell Publishing, 2004, p. 35.</ref>
==Battle of Vouillé and aftermath== [[File:Reino de los visigodos-en.svg|thumb|right|The Kingdom of the [[Visigoths]] under Alaric II]]
After a few years, however, Clovis violated the peace treaty negotiated in 502. Despite the diplomatic intervention of [[Theodoric the Great|Theodoric]], king of the [[Ostrogoths]] and father-in-law of Alaric, Clovis led his followers into Visigothic territory. Alaric was forced by his magnates to meet Clovis in the [[Battle of Vouillé]] (summer 507) near Poitiers; there the Goths were defeated and Alaric slain, according to Gregory of Tours, by Clovis himself.<ref>Wolfram, ''History of the Goths'', pp. 292f</ref>
The most serious consequence of this battle was not the loss of their possessions in [[Gaul]] to the Franks; with Ostrogothic help, much of the Gallic territory was recovered, Herwig Wolfram notes, perhaps as far as [[Toulouse]].<ref>Wolfram, ''History of the Goths'', p. 245</ref> Nor was it the loss of the royal treasury at Toulouse, which Gregory of Tours writes Clovis took into his possession.<ref name=Gregory-27/> As Peter Heather notes, the Visigothic kingdom was thrown into disarray "by the death of its king in battle."<ref>Peter Heather, ''The Goths'' (Oxford: Blackwell, 1996), p. 215</ref> Alaric's heirs were his eldest son, the illegitimate [[Gesalec]], and his younger son, the legitimate [[Amalaric]] who was still a child. Gesalec proved incompetent, and in 511 King Theodoric assumed the throne of the kingdom ostensibly on behalf of Amalaric—Heather uses the word "hijacked" to describe his action. Although Amalaric eventually became king in his own right, the political continuity of the Visigothic kingdom was broken; "Amalaric's succession was the result of new power structures, not old ones," as Heather describes it. With Amalaric's death in 531, the Visigothic kingdom entered an extended period of unrest which lasted until [[Leovigild]] assumed the throne in 568.<ref>Heather, ''The Goths'', p. 277</ref>
== Ability as king == In religion Alaric was an [[Arianism|Arian]], like all the early Visigothic nobles, but he greatly mitigated the persecution policy of his father Euric toward the [[Catholicism|Catholics]] and authorized them to hold in 506 the council of [[Agde]].<ref name="EB1911">{{EB1911|inline=y|wstitle=Alaric II.|volume=1|page=472}}</ref> He was on uneasy terms with the Catholic bishops of [[Arelate]] (modern Arles) as epitomized in the career of the Frankish [[Caesarius of Arles|Caesarius, bishop of Arles]], who was appointed bishop in 503. Caesarius was suspected of conspiring with the [[Burgundians]], whose king had married the sister of Clovis, to assist the Burgundians capture Arles. Alaric exiled him for a year to [[Bordeaux]] in Aquitania, then allowed him to return unharmed when the crisis had passed.<ref>[http://www.ccel.org/w/wace/biodict/htm/iii.iii.iv.htm Wace, ''Dictionary'']</ref>
Alaric displayed similar wisdom in political affairs by appointing a commission headed by the [[referendary]] [[Anianus (referendary)|Anianus]] to prepare an abstract of the Roman laws and imperial decrees, which would form the authoritative code for his Roman subjects. This is generally known as the ''Breviarium Alaricianum'' or [[Breviary of Alaric]].<ref name="EB1911"/>
==Legacy== The {{ill|Montagne d'Alaric|fr}} (Alaric's Mountain) near [[Carcassonne]] is named after the Visigoth king.<ref>''[http://www.rhedesium.com/the-legend-of-the-treasure-of-alaric.html The legend of the treasure of Alaric]''</ref> Local rumour has it that he left a vast treasure buried in the caves beneath the mountain.<ref>''[http://www.corbieresweb.com/Montagne-d-Alaric Montagne d’Alaric]''</ref>
The {{ill|Canal d'Alaric|fr}} (Alaric's [[Canal]]) in the [[Hautes-Pyrénées]] [[Departments of France|department]] is named after him.

'''Alcher of Clairvaux''' was a twelfth-century [[Cistercian]] monk of [[Clairvaux Abbey]]. He was once thought to be the author of two works, now attributed by many scholars to an anonymous '''pseudo-Augustine''' of the same period.<ref>http://users.skynet.be/am012324/studium/oneil/bibper15.htm states that Alcher was at Clairvaux c.1150-1175, but the authorship as increasingly doubtful.</ref><ref>Ioan P. Couliano, ''Eros and Magic in the Renaissance'' (1987) regards Alcher as more likely than Hugh of St Victor.</ref><ref>[[Beryl Smalley]], ''Studies in Medieval Thought and Learning from Abelard to Wyclif'' (1981), p. 91, agrees with Raciti that the ''De spiritu et anima'' is not by Alcher, but disagrees with his suggestion of [[Peter Comestor]] as author.</ref>
[[Thomas Aquinas]] made the traditional attribution of the ''De spiritu et anima''<ref>Also ''Liber de anima et spiritu''.</ref> to Alcher.<ref>[http://www.ccel.org/a/aquinas/summa/XP/XP090.html Summa Theologica<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.newadvent.org/summa/5090.htm SUMMA THEOLOGICA: The form of the judge in coming to the judgment (Supplementum, Q. 90)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> It is now reckoned to be a compilation of c.1170, taken from [[Alcuin]], [[Anselm of Canterbury|Anselm]], [[Bernard of Clairvaux]], [[Augustine of Hippo]], [[Cassiodorus]], [[Hugh of St Victor]], [[Isaac of Stella]], and [[Isidore of Seville]];<ref>Janet Coleman, ''Ancient and Medieval Memories: Studies in the Reconstruction of the Past'' (1992), p. 220.</ref> also [[Boethius]].<ref>http://maritain.nd.edu/jmc/etext/hwp213.htm, giving Alcher as author.</ref> It is a source for medieval views on [[self-control]],<ref>Louis G. Kelly, ''The Mirror of Grammar: Theology, Philosophy, and the Modistae'' (2002), p. 136.</ref> and the doctrine that ''the soul rules the body''.<ref>[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/09580c.htm ''Catholic Encyclopedia'', article ''Man'']</ref>
''De diligendo Deo'' is a devotional work, also traditionally attributed to Alcher.
At one point in the ''[[Summa Theologica]]'', Aquinas writes about ''De Spiritu et Anima'', "that book is not of great authority."<ref>http://www.newadvent.org/summa/1079.htm#article8</ref>
==References== * J. M. Canivez: ''Alcher'', in: Dictionnaire de Spiritualité v. 1 (1937), 294f * Leo Norpoth, ''Der Pseudo-Augustinische Traktat: De spiritu et anima'' (Dissertation, Munich, 1924; Cologne, 1971) * G. Raciti, ''L'autore del De spiritu et anima'', Rivista di filosofia neoscolastica 53 (1961) 385-401

The word "'''Alleluia'''" or "[[Hallelujah]]" (from [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] הללו יה), which literally means "Praise ye [[Yahweh|Yah]]",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/252791/hallelujah|title=Hallelujah, also spelled Alleluia|work=Encyclopædia Britannica}}</ref> a short form of "Praise [[Yahweh]]" and often rendered as "praise the Lord".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=K5ugZP7HQ6oC&pg=PA298&dq=Holman+%22praise+Jah%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjAo7npn_DSAhUJzLwKHXrbAMAQ6AEIGzAA#v=onepage&q=Holman%20%22praise%20Jah%22&f=false|title=Eugene E. Carpenter, Philip Wesley Comfort, ''Holman Treasury of Key Bible Words'' (B&H Publishing Group 2000 ISBN 9780805493528), p. 298|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=ZYoh758lNUUC&pg=PA63&dq=Brown+%22short+form+yah%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjx97CFoPDSAhVLy7wKHZB6CGIQ6AEIGzAA#v=onepage&q=Brown%20%22short%20form%20yah%22&f=false|title=Michael L. Brown, ''60 Questions Christians Ask About Jewish Beliefs and Practices'' (Chosen Books 2007 ISBN 9780800794262), p. 63|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=g4_P098HhHMC&pg=PA234&dq=Armentrout+%22praise+Yah%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj7h5ShoPDSAhUDxrwKHUmKB1MQ6AEIGzAA#v=onepage&q=Armentrout%20%22praise%20Yah%22&f=false|title= Donald S. Armentrout, Robert Boak Slocum, ''An Episcopal Dictionary of the Church'' (Church Publishing 2005 ISBN 9780898692112), p. 234|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{citation |editor1-last=St. Athanasius Academy of Orthodox Theology |title=Orthodox Study Bible |entry=notes to Psalms 104-106 |publisher=Thomas Nelson |p=751 }}</ref> From the 14th century.
The form "Alleluia" is also used to refer to a [[liturgy|liturgical chant]] in which that word is combined with verses of Scripture, usually from the [[Psalms]]. This chant is commonly used before the proclamation of the [[Gospel (liturgy)|Gospel]].
==History== The [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] word ''[[Hallelujah|Halleluya]]'' as an expression of praise to God was preserved, untranslated, by the [[Early Christians]] as a superlative expression of thanksgiving, joy, and triumph. Thus it appears in the ancient Greek [[Liturgy of St. James]], which is still used to this day by the [[Greek Orthodox Patriarch of Jerusalem|Patriarch of Jerusalem]] and, in its Syriac recension is the prototype of that used by the [[Maronites]]. In the [http://www.liturgies.net/Liturgies/Eastern/TheDivineLiturgyofMark.htm Liturgy of St. Mark], apparently the most ancient of all, we find this rubric: "Then follow ''Let us attend'', the Apostle, and the Prologue of the Alleluia."—the "Apostle" is the usual ancient Eastern title for the [[Pauline Epistles|Epistle reading]], and the "Prologue of the Alleluia" would seem to be a prayer or verse before Alleluia was sung by the choir.
==Western use== ===Roman rite=== [[Image:Alleluia Vidimus Stellam.png|right|300px|thumb|Example of a pre-Gospel Alleluia with verse.]] In the [[Roman Rite]] the word "Alleluia" is associated with joy and is especially favoured in [[Eastertide|Paschal time]], the time between [[Easter]] and [[Pentecost]], perhaps because of the association of the ''[[Hallel]]'' (Alleluia psalms) chanted at [[Passover]]. During this time, the word is added widely to verses and responses associated with prayers, to antiphons of psalms, and, during the [[Octave (liturgical)|Octave]] of Easter and on Pentecost Sunday, to the dismissal at the end of [[Mass (liturgy)|Mass]] ("[[Ite missa est]]").
On the other hand, the word "Alleluia" is excluded from the Roman liturgy during [[Lent]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Chapter II: The Structure Of The Mass, Its Elements, And Its Parts|url=http://www.usccb.org/prayer-and-worship/the-mass/general-instruction-of-the-roman-missal/girm-chapter-2.cfm|website=General Instruction Of The Roman Missal|publisher=usccb.org|accessdate=23 March 2017}}</ref> often euphemistically referred to during this time as the "A-word".{{citation needed|date=January 2018}} In pre-1970 forms of the Roman Rite it is excluded also in the pre-Lenten [[Septuagesima]] period and in [[Requiem|Masses for the Dead]]. The same word, which normally follows the [[Gloria Patri]] at the beginning of each hour of the [[Liturgy of the Hours]] and which in the present ordinary form of the Roman Rite is omitted during Lent, is replaced in pre-1970 forms by the phrase ''Laus tibi, Domine, rex aeternae gloriae'' (Praise to thee, O Lord, king of eternal glory) in Lent and the Septuagesima period.
The term "Alleluia" is used also to designate a chant beginning and ending with this word and including a verse of Scripture, in particular a chant to greet and welcome the Lord whose word will be proclaimed in the Gospel reading. The choir or a cantor sings "Alleluia". The congregation repeats this. The choir or cantor then sings a verse taken from the [[Lectionary|Mass Lectionary]] or the [[Roman Gradual]], after which the congregation again sings "Alleluia". In Lent the verse alone is sung or the word "Alleluia" is replaced by a different acclamation taken from the ''Gradual''. If singing is not used, the Alleluia and its verse may be omitted at any season.<ref>[http://www.liturgyoffice.org.uk/Resources/GIRM/Documents/GIRM.pdf General Instruction of the Roman Missal], 62−63]</ref><ref name=McNamara>[https://zenit.org/articles/liturgy-q-a-the-alleluia-before-the-gospel/ Edward McNamara, "LITURGY Q & A: The Alleluia Before the Gospel'' in ZENIT, 6 June 2017]</ref><ref>[http://www.ccwatershed.org/blog/2011/feb/28/gospel-acclamation-during-lent/ Jeff Ostrowski, "Gospel Acclamation During Lent"]</ref>
The complex [[plainchant]] setting in the Roman Gradual requires a high degree of skill and is mostly used only in monasteries and seminaries.<ref name=McNamara/> This melismatic [[Gregorian chant]] opens with the cantor singing "Alleluia". The choir repeats it, adding to the final syllable a long [[melisma]] called a [[jubilus]]. (The ''[[Liber Usualis]]'' notates the repeat with the Roman numeral "ij" (2) and continues with the jubilus.) The cantor then sings the main part of the verse, and the choir joins in on the final line. The cantor then repeats the opening Alleluia, and the choir repeats only the jubilus. The music is generally ornate, but often within a narrow range. The Alleluia for Christmas Eve, for instance, has an [[ambitus (music)|ambitus]] of only a [[perfect fifth]], a rather extreme example.
Alleluias were frequently [[Trope (music)|troped]], both with added music and text. It is believed that some early Sequences derived from syllabic text being added to the jubilus, and may be named after the opening words of the Alleluia verse. Alleluias were also among the more frequently used chants to create early [[organum|organa]], such as in the [[Winchester Troper]].
In the pre-1970 form of the Roman-Rite Mass the Alleluia and its verse is replaced during Lent and Septuagesima time by a [[Tract (liturgy)|Tract]]. On the other hand, during Eastertide the [[Gradual]] is replaced with an Alleluia chant, thus putting two such chants before the Gospel reading.
==Eastern uses== ===Byzantine rite=== In the [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Eastern Orthodox]] and [[Eastern Catholic Churches|Greek-Catholic]] Churches, after reading the Apostle (Epistle) at the [[Divine Liturgy]], the [[Reader (liturgy)#Orthodoxy|Reader]] announces which of the [[Octoechos|Eight Tones]] the Alleluia is to be chanted in. The response of the choir is always the same: "Alleluia, alleluia, alleluia." What differs is the tone in which it is sung, and the [[stichera]] (psalm verses) which are intoned by the Reader.
The Alleluia is paired with the [[Prokeimenon]] which preceded the reading of the Apostle. There may be either one or two Alleluias, depending upon the number of Prokeimena (there may be up to three readings from the Apostle, but never be more than two Prokeimena and Alleluia).
In the Russian/Slavic order, the Alleluia is intoned in one of the two following manners, depending upon the number of Prokeimena (The Antiochian/Byzantine practice is slightly different):
====One Alleluia==== :''Deacon:'' "Let us attend." :''Reader:'' "Alleluia in the ____ Tone." :''Choir:'' "Alleluia, alleluia, alleluia." :The Reader then chants the first sticheron of the Alleluia. :''Choir:'' "Alleluia, alleluia, alleluia." :The Reader then chants the second sticheron of the Alleluia. :''Choir:'' "Alleluia, alleluia, alleluia."
====Two Alleluias==== :''Deacon:'' "Let us attend." :''Reader:'' "Alleluia in the ____ Tone:" Then he immediately chants the first sticheron of the first Alleluia. :''Choir:'' "Alleluia, alleluia, alleluia." :The Reader then chants the second sticheron of the first Alleluia. :''Choir:'' "Alleluia, alleluia, alleluia." :''Reader:'' "In the ____ Tone:" And he chants the first sticheron of the second Alleluia. :''Choir:'' "Alleluia, alleluia, alleluia."
====Lenten Alleluia==== Among the Orthodox, the chanting of Alleluia does not cease during Lent, as it does in the West. This is in accordance with the Orthodox approach to fasting, which is one of sober joy. During the weekdays of [[Great Lent]] and certain days during the lesser Lenten seasons ([[Nativity Fast]], [[Apostles' Fast]], and [[Dormition Fast]]), the celebration of the Divine Liturgy on weekdays is not permitted. Instead, Alleluia is chanted at [[Matins]]. Since this chanting of Alleluia at Matins is characteristic of Lenten services, Lenten days are referred to as "Days with Alleluia."
The Alleluia at Matins is not related to scripture readings or Prokeimena; instead, it replaces [[Theos Kyrios|"God is the Lord..."]] It is sung in the Tone of the Week and is followed by the Hymns to the Trinity (''Triadica'') in the same tone (see [[Octoechos (liturgy)#Use|Octoechos]] for an explanation of the eight-week cycle of tones).
"God is the Lord..." would normally be intoned by the deacon, but since the deacon does not serve on days with Alleluia, it is intoned by the priest. He stands in front of the [[icon]] of Christ on the [[Iconostasis]], and says:
:''Priest:'' "Alleluia in the ____ Tone: Out of the night my spirit waketh at dawn unto Thee, O God, for Thy commandments are a light upon the earth." :''Choir:'' "Alleluia, alleluia, alleluia." :''Priest:'' "Learn righteousness, ye that dwell upon the earth." :''Choir:'' "Alleluia, alleluia, alleluia." :''Priest:'' "Zeal shall lay hold upon an uninstructed people." :''Choir:'' "Alleluia, alleluia, alleluia." :''Priest:'' "Add more evils upon them, O Lord, lay more evils upon them that are glorious upon the earth." :''Choir:'' "Alleluia, alleluia, alleluia."
====Alleluia for the departed==== Alleluia is also chanted to a special melody at [[Christian burial|funerals]], [[Panikhida|memorial services]] (Greek: ''Parastas'', Slavonic: ''Panikhida''), and on [[Saturdays of the Dead]]. Again, it is chanted in place of "God is the Lord...", but this time is followed by the [[Troparia]] of the Departed.
The Alleluia is intoned by the deacon (or the priest, if no deacon is available):
:''Deacon:'' "Alleluia, in the 8th tone: Blessed are they whom Thou hast chosen and taken unto Thyself, O Lord." :''Choir'': "Alleluia, Alleluia, Alleluia." :''Deacon:'' "Their memory is from generation to generation." :''Choir'': "Alleluia, Alleluia, Alleluia." :''Deacon:'' "Their souls will dwell amid good things." :''Choir'': "Alleluia, Alleluia, Alleluia."
On Saturdays of the Dead, which are celebrated several times throughout the year, the [[prokeimenon]] at Vespers is also replaced with Alleluia, which is chanted in the following manner:
:''Deacon:'' "Alleluia, in the 8th tone. :''Choir'': "Alleluia, Alleluia, Alleluia." :''Deacon:'' "Blessed are they whom Thou hast chosen and taken unto Thyself, O Lord." :''Choir'': "Alleluia, Alleluia, Alleluia." :''Deacon:'' "Their memory is from generation to generation." :''Choir'': "Alleluia, Alleluia, Alleluia."
====Other uses==== [[Gospel (liturgy)|Gospel readings]] are appointed for other services as well, particularly those in the [[Trebnik]]. A number of these are preceded by an Alleluia, in the same manner as that chanted at the Divine Liturgy, though sometimes there are no stichera (psalm verses).
During the [[Sacred Mystery]] (Sacrament) of [[Baptism]], in addition to the Alleluia before the Gospel, the choir also chants an Alleluia while the priest pours the [[Oil of Catechumens]] into the [[baptismal font]].
==See also== * ''[[Alle Psallite Cum Luya]]'' * [[Hallelujah]] * [[Eastertide]] * [[Gregorian chant]]

'''Alternatives assessment''' or '''alternatives analysis''' is a problem-solving approach used in [[environmental design]], [[environmental technology|technology]], and [[environmental policy|policy]]. It aims to minimize environmental harm by comparing multiple potential solutions in the context of a specific problem, design goal, or policy objective. It is intended to inform decision-making in situations with many possible courses of action, a wide range of variables to consider, and significant degrees of uncertainty. Alternatives assessment was originally developed as a robust way to guide [[Precautionary principle|precautionary]] action and avoid [[Analysis paralysis|paralysis by analysis]]; authors such as O'Brien have presented alternatives assessment as an approach that is complementary to [[risk assessment]], the dominant decision-making approach in environmental policy.<ref name="obrien_2000">{{Cite book| publisher = MIT Press| isbn = 0-262-15051-4| last = O'Brien| first = Mary| title = Making better environmental decisions: An alternative to risk assessment| location = Cambridge| date = 2000}}</ref> Likewise, Ashford has described the similar concept of ''technology options analysis'' as a way to generate innovative solutions to the problems of industrial pollution more effectively than through risk-based regulation.<ref name="ashford_1994">{{Cite book| publisher = Resources for the Future| isbn = 0-915707-74-8| pages = 275–314| editor = Adam M. Finkel| editor2 = Dominic Golding| last = Ashford| first = Nicholas A.| title = Worst things first? The debate over risk-based national environmental priorities| chapter = An innovation-based strategy for the environment| location = Washington, DC| date = 1994}}</ref><ref name="ashford_2005">{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1080/10807030590919918| issn = 1549-7860| volume = 11| issue = 1| pages = 85–96| last = Ashford| first = Nicholas A.| title = Incorporating science, technology, fairness, and accountability in environmental, health, and safety decisions| journal = Human and Ecological Risk Assessment: An International Journal| date = 2005-02-23}}</ref>
Alternatives assessment is practiced in a variety of settings, including but not limited to [[green chemistry]], [[sustainable design]], supply-chain chemicals management, and chemicals policy.<ref name="geiser_2015">{{Cite book| publisher = The MIT Press| isbn = 978-0-262-51206-0| last = Geiser| first = Ken| title = Chemicals without harm: Policies for a sustainable world| location = Cambridge, Mass.| series = Urban and industrial environments| date = 2015}}</ref> One prominent application area for alternatives assessment is the substitution of hazardous chemicals with safer alternatives, also known as chemical alternatives assessment.<ref name="harrison_hester">{{Cite book| publisher = Royal Society of Chemistry| isbn = 978-1-84973-723-4| editor = Roy M. Harrison| editor2 = Ronald E. Hester| title = Chemical alternatives assessments| location = Cambridge| series = Issues in Environmental Science and Technology| date = 2013}}</ref>
== Methodology ==
Generally, alternatives assessment involves considering a number of possible options to achieve a specific objective, and applying a principled comparative analysis. The objective is usually to improve the environmental performance or safety of a specific product, material, process, or other activity. Potential alternatives considered in the analysis may include different chemical substances, materials, technologies, methods of use, or even extensive redesign to enable new ways of achieving the objective while avoiding the problem. Understanding the consequences of each available option is central to the process and goals of alternatives assessment, because this helps avoid decisions that substitute one problem with another (unknown) problem. The comparative analysis can involve any number of criteria for evaluating options, and these are typically focused on environmental health and sustainability.<ref name="lowell_fwk">{{Cite conference| publisher = Lowell Center for Sustainable Production| last1 = Rossi| first1 = Mark| last2 = Tickner| first2 = Joel| last3 = Geiser| first3 = Ken| title = Alternatives assessment framework of the Lowell Center for Sustainable Production| location = Lowell, MA| url=http://www.sustainableproduction.org/downloads/FinalAltsAssess06_000.pdf| date = 2006}}</ref>
There is no single protocol that dictates how options should be identified, evaluated, and compared in an alternatives assessment. Rather, a number of different alternatives assessment ''frameworks'' exist, which serve to structure decision-making and to enable systematic consideration of the key factors. Jacobs and colleagues identify six major components of alternatives assessment: evaluation of [[Hazard (risk)|hazard]], exposure, [[Life-cycle assessment|life cycle]] impacts, technical feasibility, and economic feasibility; and an overall decision-making strategy.<ref name="jacobs_2016">{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1289/ehp.1409581| issn = 0091-6765| volume = 124| issue = 3| last1 = Jacobs| first1 = Molly M.| last2 = Malloy| first2 = Timothy F.| last3 = Tickner| first3 = Joel A.| last4 = Edwards| first4 = Sally| title = Alternatives assessment frameworks: Research needs for the informed substitution of hazardous chemicals| journal = Environmental Health Perspectives| date = 2016-03-01| pmid=26339778| pmc=4786344}}</ref>
One major framework, the [https://www.uml.edu/research/lowell-center/ Lowell Center for Sustainable Production] Alternatives Assessment Framework,<ref name="lowell_fwk" /> conceives of alternatives assessment very broadly, as a reflexive problem-solving process that recognizes the social and technical complexity of environmental problems. It emphasizes aspects such as stakeholder participation, transparency of the process, and open discussion of values in decision-making. Most other frameworks are more narrow and primarily focused on technical aspects.<ref name="jacobs_2016" />
=== Chemical alternatives assessment ===
Chemical alternatives assessment (or ''substitution of hazardous chemicals'') is the use of alternatives assessment for finding safer and environmentally preferable design options to reduce or eliminate the use of hazardous chemical substances. Safer alternatives to hazardous chemicals may simply be other chemical substances, or may involve deeper changes in material or product design.<ref name="lavoie_2010">{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1021/es1015789| issn = 1520-5851| volume = 44| issue = 24| pages = 9244–9249| last1 = Lavoie| first1 = Emma T.| last2 = Heine| first2 = Lauren G.| last3 = Holder| first3 = Helen| last4 = Rossi| first4 = Mark S.| last5 = Lee| first5 = Robert E.| last6 = Connor| first6 = Emily A.| last7 = Vrabel| first7 = Melanie A.| last8 = DiFiore| first8 = David M.| last9 = Davies| first9 = Clive L.| title = Chemical alternatives assessment: Enabling substitution to safer chemicals| journal = Environmental Science & Technology| date = 2010-12-15| pmid=21062050}}</ref><ref name="tickner_2015">{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1021/es503328m| issn = 1520-5851| volume = 49| issue = 2| pages = 742–749| last1 = Tickner| first1 = Joel A.| last2 = Schifano| first2 = Jessica N.| last3 = Blake| first3 = Ann| last4 = Rudisill| first4 = Catherine| last5 = Mulvihill| first5 = Martin J.| title = Advancing safer alternatives through functional substitution| journal = Environmental Science & Technology| date = 2015-01-20}}</ref> Chemical alternatives assessment aims to provide the basis for well-informed decision-making by thoroughly characterizing chemicals and materials (and other design options) across a wide range of environmental and health impact categories. The rationale for this is to avoid shifting environmental health burdens from one category of impacts to another (e.g., substituting a [[carcinogen]]ic chemical with a [[neurotoxin|neurotoxic]] one), and to minimize the [[unintended consequences]] of decisions made under conditions of uncertainty and ignorance—in other words, to prevent "[[Hazard substitution#Regrettable substitutions|regrettable substitutions]]", where an alternative appeared better based on limited knowledge, but turned out to be worse or equally bad.<ref name="howard_2014">{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1016/j.chemosphere.2014.02.034| issn = 0045-6535| last = Howard| first = Gregory J.| title = Chemical alternatives assessment: The case of flame retardants| journal = Chemosphere| date = 2014| volume=116| pages=112–117}}</ref>
An array of methodologies and tools for chemical alternatives assessment have been developed worldwide and have been deployed in a variety of industry sectors.<ref name="harrison_hester" /><ref name="oecd_toolbox">{{Cite web| last = Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development| title = OECD substitution and alternatives assessment toolbox| url = http://www.oecdsaatoolbox.org/}}</ref> Chemical alternatives assessment frameworks include [[chemical hazard]] assessment methods that consider a wide range of hazard [[Clinical endpoint|endpoints]], such as those defined in the [[Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labelling of Chemicals|Globally Harmonized System]] or the [[GreenScreen for Safer Chemicals]].
=== Examples ===
* The Massachusetts Toxics Use Reduction Institute has conducted alternatives assessments for the substitution of hazardous substances like lead and formaldehyde.<ref name="turi_five">{{Cite web| author = Toxics Use Reduction Institute| title = Five Chemicals Alternatives Assessment Study| accessdate = 2016-07-31| date = 2006| url = http://www.turi.org/TURI_Publications/TURI_Methods_Policy_Reports/Five_Chemicals_Alternatives_Assessment_Study._2006}}</ref> * The San Francisco Department of Environment has conducted alternatives assessments to identify environmentally and economically preferable alternatives to conventional dry cleaning technology.<ref name="sfenv_dryclean">http://sfenvironment.org/download/dry-cleaning-alternatives-assessment</ref> * Electronics manufacturer [[Hewlett-Packard]] uses the [[GreenScreen for Safer Chemicals]] chemical hazard assessment method in product R&D.<ref name="holder_2013">{{Cite book| publisher = Royal Society of Chemistry| isbn = 978-1-84973-723-4| pages = 157–176| editor = R. M. Harrison| editor2 = R. E. Hester| last1 = Holder| first1 = Helen A.| last2 = Mazurkiewicz| first2 = P. H.| last3 = Robertson| first3 = C. A.| last4 = Wray| first4 = C. A.| title = Chemical alternatives assessments| chapter = Hewlett-Packard’s use of the GreenScreen for safer chemicals| location = Cambridge| series = Issues in Environmental Science and Technology| date = 2013}}</ref>
== Practice of alternatives assessment ==
Scientists from a variety of government agencies, academic institutions, non-profit organizations, and firms have contributed to developing the practice of alternatives assessment.
=== In the United States ===
Scientific research in the US federal government has contributed to alternatives assessment frameworks and practices. In 2014 the [[National Research Council (United States)|US National Research Council]] released a chemical alternatives assessment framework developed by an expert working group.<ref name="nrc_2014">{{Cite book| publisher = The National Academies Press| isbn = 978-0-309-31013-0| author = National Research Council (US)| title = A framework to guide selection of chemical alternatives| location = Washington, D.C| url=http://www.nap.edu/catalog/18872/a-framework-to-guide-selection-of-chemical-alternatives| date = 2014}}</ref> Prior to this, the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|US Environmental Protection Agency]] ran a program called ''Design for the Environment'' (now called [https://www.epa.gov/saferchoice Safer Choice]), which developed chemical alternatives assessment methodology<ref name="lavoie_2010" /> and created partnerships to undertake numerous alternatives assessments for chemicals of concern in products.<ref name="usepa_dfe">{{Cite web| author = US Environmental Protection Agency| title = Design for the Environment alternatives assessments| url = https://www.epa.gov/saferchoice/design-environment-alternatives-assessments}}</ref>
Alternatives assessment has featured in some state-level chemicals policies and regulatory activities. The [[Massachusetts Toxics Use Reduction Institute]] has provided public technical assistance for "toxics use reduction planning", which includes alternatives assessment.<ref name="eliason_2011">{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1016/j.jclepro.2010.05.011| issn = 0959-6526| volume = 19| issue = 5| pages = 517–526| last1 = Eliason| first1 = Pamela| last2 = Morose| first2 = Gregory| title = Safer alternatives assessment: The Massachusetts process as a model for state governments| journal = Journal of Cleaner Production| date = 2011}}</ref> More recently, the [[California Department of Toxic Substances Control]] is implementing new regulations that require firms to undertake alternatives assessments for selected priority chemicals in products.<ref name="ca_dtsc_aa">{{Cite web| author = California Department of Toxic Substances Control| title = Alternatives analysis| work = Safer Consumer Products (SCP)| url = http://www.dtsc.ca.gov/SCP/AA.cfm}}</ref> The Interstate Chemicals Clearinghouse, an association of state governments, has also produced its own guide to alternatives assessment.<ref name="ic2_aa">{{Citation| author = Interstate Chemicals Clearinghouse| title = IC2 Alternatives assessment guide, version 1.0| url=http://theic2.org/article/download-pdf/file_name/IC2_AA_Guide_Version_1.0.pdf| date = 2013}}</ref>
Some US-based companies have begun to use chemical alternatives assessment to address chemical safety issues in supply chains. For example, firms that participate in the [http://bizngo.org/ Business-NGO Working Group for Safer Chemicals and Sustainable Materials] have produced their own guidance for chemical alternatives assessment.<ref name="bizngo_aa">{{Citation| author = Business-NGO Working Group for Safer Chemicals and Sustainable Materials (BizNGO)| title = BizNGO chemical alternatives assessment protocol| url=http://www.bizngo.org/alternatives-assessment/chemical-alternatives-assessment-protocol| date = 2011-11-30}}</ref>
=== In the European Union ===
The Sweden-based non-governmental organization [[ChemSec]] has been active in developing resources and tools for the substitution of hazardous chemicals. The [http://www.subsport.eu/ Substitution support portal (SUBSPORT)] is an EU-based collaboratively-developed resource for chemical substitution.<ref name="lissner_2011">{{Cite journal| doi = 10.2190/NS.21.3.l| issn = 1541-3772| volume = 21| issue = 3| pages = 477–497| last1 = Lissner| first1 = Lothar| last2 = Romano| first2 = Dolores| title = Substitution for hazardous chemicals on an international level—The approach of the European project "SUBSPORT"| journal = NEW SOLUTIONS: A Journal of Environmental and Occupational Health Policy| date = 2011-01-01| pmid=22001043}}</ref> It includes alternatives assessment case studies.

{{Cleanup|date=November 2009}} [[File:Angel f-artificial intelligence.svg|thumb|right|200px|Angel_F]] '''Angel_F''' is a fictional child [[artificial intelligence]] that has been used in worldwide art performances focused on the issues of digital liberties, [[intellectual property]] and on the evolution of language and behaviour in information society. The character was created by [[Salvatore Iaconesi]] in 2007 as a hack to the '''Biodoll''' art performance by Italian artist '''Franca Formenti'''.
The project revolves around the story of the technological sensual relationship between the Biodoll, a digital prostitute, and professor '''[[Derrick de Kerckhove]]''', culminating in the birth of the young artificial intelligence. The digital child morphed from a [[spyware]] program capturing internet users' browsing activities in order to gather text to feed an algorithmic language generating system (thus letting the "child" learn how to speak) and became a digital personality used by the artists for both online and real-world performances.
The project was later joined by '''Oriana Persico''' who curated communication and part of the theoretical approaches of the action.
The Angel_F project has been featured in books, magazines, national televisions, and has been invited to many worldwide conferences and events, both academic and artistic.
On one occasion, in October 2007, Angel_F attended the [[Internet Governance Forum]] (IGF) in Rio de Janeiro as the only digital being invited to speak: the young artificial intelligence was featured with a video message concerning the struggles for digital liberties, privacy, knowledge sharing and access to networks and technologies.
==History==
Angel_F is an acronym which stads for ''Autonomous Non Generative E-volitive Life_Form''. The project was born in 2007 and resulted from the fusion of two contemporary art performances.
Franca Formenti, an Italian artist living in Varese, invented the Biodoll <ref name="bazzichelli">{{cite book | last1 = Bazzichelli | first1 = Tatiana | title = [[Networking. La rete come arte]] | publisher = [[Costa & Nolan]] | year= 2006 | isbn = 88-7437-047-4 }}</ref> character in 2002 which began making its appearances first on the network and later in the physical world by using what were called "clones": young women, prostitutes, pornographic starlets, transsexuals and models interpreting the role of a digital prostitute. The Biodoll was an art performance focused on research emerging from the network of new forms of sexualities, and on the analysis of changes brought on by this transformation to the concepts of private and public spaces, privacy, and the possibility of creating multiple fluid identities through language and digital media. At the time the Biodoll character claimed a role in professor Derrick de Kerckhove's life, narratively seducing him and alluring him into joining in the performance, becoming the Biodoll's favourite lover.
The theme of fertility has always been central to the Biodoll performance: the digital prostitute was a wombless clone but desired giving birth to a son, the '''Bloki'''.
In a process starting in 2006 and ending in February 2007, Salvatore Iaconesi (xDxD.vs.xDxD) used his '''Talker''' <ref name="pagliarini">{{cite book | last = Pagliarini | first = Luigi | first2 = Elisa |last2=Frauenfelder |first3=Clementina |last3=Gily |first4=Domenico |last4=Jervolino |first5=Iginio Sisto |last5=Lancia |first6=Francesca |last6=Marone |first7=Alberto |last7=Oliviero |first8=Santa |last8=Palumbo |first9=Dunia |last9=Pepe |first10=Rocco |last10=Pititto |first11=Franco |last11=Rubinacci |first12=Francesca |last12=Serra |first13=Rosetta |last13=Zan | title = Intelligenza Polimorfa on Scienze cognitive e aperture pedagogiche. Nuovi orizzonti nella formazione degli insegnanti | publisher = Franco Angeli | year = 2007 | location = Rome | isbn = 978-88-464-9547-1 }}</ref> linguistic artificial intelligence to animate the digital child conceived with prof. Derrick de Kerckhove: ''Angel_F''.
Iaconesi and Persico met in November 2006 and immediately started collaborating on the birth of Angel_F.
Angel_F was designed as a synthetic digital being composed through narrative, technological and [[cognitive psychology]] layers. The objective was to create iconic characteristics that resulted in being evocative and able to mimic human life up to a level in which bringing up a symbolic dialogue was possible. On the other side, the artificial identity was to implement and expose the cultural, emotional and relational ways that were typical of networked [[Ecology#Ecosystem|social ecosystems]], among those technologies, systems and infrastructures that entered and shaped people's daily lives.
The young '''[[Artificial life|digital being]]''' mimicked the evolution of a human baby: initially conceived inside the website of its digital mother it emulated the birth of a child by using the metaphor of a virus developing inside a website, taking progressively more space in the domain's databases and interfaces. Content was produced through the software by using small browser-based spyware techniques, through which Angel_F could [[Inference|infer]] the list of major portals that had been visited by the website's users.
The Biodoll website was invaded by this growing presence and, thus, Angel_F was born.
The Artificial Intelligence (AI) component of Angel_F was derived from another project, Talker,<ref name="talker">{{cite web|last=Iaconesi |first=Salvatore |title=Talker |url=http://www.artisopensource.net/talkers/index2.html |accessdate=4 October 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100620081106/http://www.artisopensource.net/talkers/index2.html |archivedate=20 June 2010 }}</ref> through which internet users could build up the AI's linguistic network by feeding it their text and web clips. Angel_F used this component to generate sentences and phrases, publishing them on the interface and on selected blogs.
The parallel between the growth of the AI and that of a child kept building up and, just as children learn how to speak and act by observing their parents and the people around them, Angel_F used its spyware and AI components to learn, to navigate websites and web portals using '''[[web crawler]]''' based techniques, and to interact with other people by using the contents hosted and generated in its database to create surreal dialogues in blogs and websites.
A virtual school was created, called '''Talker Mind''',<ref name="talkermind">{{cite web|last=Iaconesi |first=Salvatore |title=Talker Mind |url=http://www.artisopensource.net/talker_mind/ |accessdate=4 October 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100620083741/http://www.artisopensource.net/talker_mind/ |archivedate=20 June 2010 |df= }}</ref> to narratively continue the AI's growth. Five professors ([[Massimo Canevacci]], [[Antonio Caronia]], [[Carlo Formenti]], [[Derrick de Kerckhove]] and [[Luigi Pagliarini]]) fed their texts and academic articles to Angel_F, simulating virtual asynchronous lessons by using a multi-blog structure.<ref name="blogart">{{cite web|last=Agricola de Cologne |first=Wilfred |title=a+b blogart? |url=http://www.javamuseum.org/blog/?page_id=41 |accessdate=4 October 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090212161016/http://www.javamuseum.org/blog/?page_id=41 |archivedate=12 February 2009 }}</ref>
A [[peer-to-peer]] system was also created at the time, named '''Presence'''. Its interface resembled the one of [[History of video game consoles (third generation)|8-bit videogames]] and the peer to peer users travelled in a starry space and were able to perform standard [[Instant messaging|Instant Messaging]] tasks, such as [[Online chat|chat]] and [[file sharing]]. The interactions were possible both among humans and digital beings. Angel_F was the first user of the Presence peer to peer system.
Angel_F entered the physical world as a baby-stroller mounted laptop computer that was used to let the digital child join events and conferences held worldwide.
The first public space performance was held in [[Milan]], when the Biodoll distributed a generative ''free press'' publication <ref name="bloki1">{{cite press release | title = Bloki FreePreXXX | date = 20 February 2007 | url = http://www.digicult.it/2007/biodoll.asp | accessdate = 4 October 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091023080104/http://www.digicult.it/2007/biodoll.asp| archivedate= 23 October 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> (called the '''Bloki FreePreXXX''', its text was generated algorithmically and inserted into a prepared graphic layout).
The second performance was held in [[Rome]], at the '''[[Forte Prenestino]]''' on June 14, 2007, with a massive playroom created through computational graphics that people could interact with and that were generated by the AI.
Angel_F performed all over the world, both in artistic contexts and in academic ones. It was also used for the communication strategy of several activist groups on the themes of intellectual property and digital freedoms.
On '''June 22, 2007''' Angel_F presented the closing remarks for an '''Ipotesi per Assurdo''' <ref name="ipotesi">{{cite web | last = Iaconesi | first = Salvatore | title = Ipotesi per Assurdo | url = http://www.slideshare.net/xdxd/ipotesi-per-assurdo | accessdate = 4 October 2009}}</ref><ref name="fiorello">{{cite web | last = Cortiana | first = Fiorello | title = Condividi la Conoscenza | url = http://db.formez.it/ArchivioNews.nsf/7fab7a7a86803f49c1256ae800400917/e0fe4b680b8434cac12572f700334708/Testo/M2/condividi_conoscenza3_programma.pdf?OpenElement&ei=7-TJSp_AO86OsAb085ThDg&usg=AFQjCNHk5FlR8u4tI39Rv-PQAro3_D_0KQ&sig2=oDMREwxxZ76tCx919Tpuww | accessdate = 5 October 2009}}</ref> (Absurd Hypothesis) with Salvatore Iaconesi and Oriana Persico at the [[IULM| IULM University in Milan]], discussing the possibilities for an ecosystemic, sustainable reinvention of corporations.
On '''July 28, 2007''', hundreds of people at '''LiberaFesta''' (Free Party) in Rome listened to Angel_F in a speech discussing new politics and ''hacker ethics''.
On '''October 2007''', Angel_F was presented live at the ''FE/MALE 2'' event, as an example of an atypical family during a public debate on new sexualities and social change.
Again in '''October 2007''', Angel_F made a series of public performances [[Florence]]'s '''Festival della Creatività''' (Festival of Creativity), an institutional event held periodically to showcase Italy's and other countries' best technological projects. During the festival Derrick de Kerckhove publicly recognized the little AI as his digital son.<ref name="derickpapa">{{cite web | last = de Kerckhove | first = Derrick | title = Festival della Creatività | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UD3UVluoF0c | accessdate = 4 October 2009}}</ref>
On '''October 2008''', Angel_F was used at a public event on a European scale called '''Freedom not Fear''' discussing privacy and civil liberties.<ref name="fnf">{{cite web | title = Freedom Not Fear | url = http://www.artsblog.it/post/2428/incursione-digitale-di-angel_f-e-del-super-avatar-al-freedom-not-fear-in-esclusiva-per-i-lettori-di-artsblog | accessdate = 5 October 2009}}</ref>
Lately ('''July 2009''') Angel_F has been seen with its digital father Derrick de Kerckhove to protest against Italy's harsh politics on freedom of speech.<ref name="angelino">{{cite web | title = Blogger Strike in Piazza Navona | url = http://www.artsblog.it/post/3645/angelino-is-watching-you | accessdate = 5 October 2009}}</ref>
A case of censorship saw Angel_F involved, when it was not allowed to post its contribution to the '''DFIR''' (Dialogue Forum for Internet Rights) held in ''Rome'' on '''September 2007''' in preparation for Rio de Janeiro's Internet Governance Forum (IGF) edition.<ref name="vetere">{{cite web|last=Vetere |first=Guido |title=L'identità di Angel_F |url=http://guidovetere.nova100.ilsole24ore.com/2007/09/angel_f.html |accessdate=4 October 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100114081406/http://guidovetere.nova100.ilsole24ore.com/2007/09/angel_f.html |archivedate=14 January 2010 }}</ref> The case quickly turned into a collaboration among the involved parties <ref name="dicorinto">[[:it:Arturo Di Corinto|Arturo di Corinto]]</ref> and Angel_F was invited to the global event in Brazil where it was the only present digital being: on that occasion Angel_F contributed a videomessage, in the digital freedoms workshop, which suggested some ideas for action to the [[United Nations]] and to all the parties involved in the global ''IGF'' organization.
==Background==
Angel_F mixes real technologically advanced systems with a poetic, narrative approach. In the performance real and not-real are constantly intermixed, and the concepts, techniques and characteristics of the whole project have been analyzed multiple times in several international academic events and research projects.
Angel_F's authors coined the term '''[[NeoRealismo Virtuale]]''' (Virtual NeoRealism) to identify the practices created and used in the project. Its intent is to describe and represent the contemporary world in its hybrid analog/digital form, with digital technologies progressively interacting and integrating to the physical world, even on the level of personal identity and private/public space definitions.
The '''Glocal & Outsiders conference''' <ref name="kera">{{cite web | last = Kera | first = Denisa | title = Glocal and Outsiders | url = http://glocaloutsiders.wordpress.com/ | accessdate = 4 October 2009}}</ref> held in '''[[Prague]]''' at the ''[[Academy of Sciences of the Czech Republic|Academy of Sciences]]'' in '''2007''' was the first academic presentation of the Angel_F project, together with the ''Biodoll''.
By '''December 2007''' several international associations,<ref name="frontiere">{{cite web|title=Frontiere Digitali |url=http://tv.frontieredigitali.net/convegni/liberazione-2007/angel_f-liberafesta-roma-luglio-2007 |accessdate=4 October 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723132210/http://tv.frontieredigitali.net/convegni/liberazione-2007/angel_f-liberafesta-roma-luglio-2007 |archivedate=23 July 2011 }}</ref><ref name="arcoiris">{{cite web|title=Arcoiris TV |url=http://www.arcoiris.tv/modules.php?name=Lettere&op=esteso&id=3328 |accessdate=4 October 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723054811/http://www.arcoiris.tv/modules.php?name=Lettere&op=esteso&id=3328 |archivedate=23 July 2011 }}</ref> and scientific researchers had been involved with Angel_F, eventually producing the system and process used to set up the ''Talker Mind'' digital school for the AI with Angel_F's professors.
On '''March 2008''' the [[Tecnológico de Monterrey]] university in [[Mexico City]] organized the '''Computer Art Congress 2''' <ref name="cac2">{{cite web | title = Computer Art Congress | url = http://europia.org/CAC2/ | accessdate = 4 October 2009}}</ref> international event, featuring Angel_F's project among with the ones by scientific researchers worldwide.<ref name="cac2book">{{cite book | last1 = Zreik | first1 = Khaldoun | last2 = Reyes García | first2 = Everardo | first3 = Marc |last3=Veyrat |first4=Daniel |last4=Bouillot |first5=Jacques |last5=Ibanez Bueno |first6=Oriana |last6=Persico |first7=Salvatore |last7=Iaconesi | title = Angel_f, in Computer art congress: CAC 2 | publisher = Europia | year = 2008 | location = Mexico City | id = {{Listed Invalid ISBN|978-2-909285-45-0}} }}</ref>
On '''July 2008''', the project was presented in [[Austria]] at the ''[[Planetary Collegium]]'''s '''[[Planetary_Collegium#The_Consciousness_Reframed_Conferences|Consciousness Reframed 9]]''' conference, together with the ''NeoRealismo Virtuale''.<ref name="cr9">{{cite book | last1 = Ascott | first1 = Roy | last2 = Bast | first2 = Gerald | last3= Fiel | first3= Wolfgang | first4 = Roy |last4=Ascott |first5=Gerald |last5=Bast |first6=Wolfgang |last6=Fiel |first7=Margarete |last7=Jahrmann |first8=Ruth |last8=Schnell |first9=Oriana |last9=Persico |first10=Salvatore |last10=Iaconesi | title = Technologically-aware ecosystems in Art and Society, New realities: Being Syncretic | publisher = Springer | year = 2008 | location = New York | isbn = 978-3-211-78890-5 }}</ref>
As of the end of 2009, the project continues, both artistically and academically.
A book is about to be published in '''November 2009''' by ''Castelvecchi Editore'' in Italy, titled '''Angel F. Diario di una intelligenza artificiale''' <ref name="angel">{{cite book | last1 = Iaconesi | first1 = Salvatore | last2 = Persico | first2 = Oriana | title = Angel F. Diario di una intelligenza artificiale | publisher = Castelvecchi | year = 2009 | location = Rome | isbn = 978-88-7615-342-6 }}</ref> (Angel_F, the diaries of an Artificial Intelligence).
