{{Infobox medical intervention | name = Spinal cord stimulator | image = Anterior thoracic SCS.jpg | caption = Anterior view X-ray of a spinal cord stimulator (SCS) implanted in the thoracic spine | alt = | pronounce = | synonyms = | ICD10 = | ICD9 = | ICD9unlinked = | MeshID = | LOINC = | other_codes = | MedlinePlus = | eMedicine = }}
A '''Spinal Cord Stimulator''' (SCS) or Dorsal Column Stimulator (DCS) is a type of implantable [[neuromodulation]] device (sometimes called a "pain pacemaker") that is used to send electrical signals to select areas of the [[spinal cord]] (dorsal columns) for the treatment of certain pain conditions. SCS is a consideration for people who have a pain condition that has not responded to more conservative therapy.<ref name=Uptodate>{{cite web |last1=McKenzie-Brown |first1=Anne Marie |title=Spinal cord stimulation: Placement and management |url=https://www.uptodate.com/contents/spinal-cord-stimulation-placement-and-management?source=search_result&search=spinal%20cord%20stimuator&selectedTitle=1~150 |publisher=UptoDate |date=November 1, 2016}}</ref>
In the United States, Failed Back Surgery Syndrome is the most common use while in Europe the most common use is peripheral ischemia.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Eldabe |first=Sam |last2=Kumar |first2=Krishna |last3=Buchser |first3=Eric |last4=Taylor |first4=Rod S. |date=July 2010 |title=An analysis of the components of pain, function, and health-related quality of life in patients with failed back surgery syndrome treated with spinal cord stimulation or conventional medical management |journal=Neuromodulation |volume=13 |issue=3 |pages=201–209 |doi=10.1111/j.1525-1403.2009.00271.x |pmid=21992833}}</ref>
As of 2014 the FDA had approved SCS as a treatment for [[Failed Back Surgery Syndrome|failed back surgery syndrome]] (FBSS), chronic pain, [[Complex regional pain syndrome|Complex Regional Pain Syndrome]], intractable angina, as well as visceral abdominal and perineal pain<ref name=Uptodate/> and pain in the extremities from nerve damage.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Song |first=Jason J. |last2=Popescu |first2=Adrian |last3=Bell |first3=Russell L. |date=May 2014 |title=Present and potential use of spinal cord stimulation to control chronic pain |journal=Pain Physician |volume=17 |issue=3 |pages=235–246 |pmid=24850105}}</ref>
==Medical uses== The most common use of SCS is [[Failed back syndrome|failed back surgery syndrome]] (FBSS) in the United States and peripheral ischemic pain in Europe.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Turner |first=J. A. |last2=Loeser |first2=J. D. |last3=Bell |first3=K. G. |date=December 1995 |title=Spinal cord stimulation for chronic low back pain: a systematic literature synthesis |journal=Neurosurgery |volume=37 |issue=6 |pages=1088–1095; discussion 1095–1096 |pmid=8584149 |doi=10.1097/00006123-199512000-00008}}</ref><ref name=Patel2015>{{Cite journal |last=Patel |first=Vikram B. |last2=Wasserman |first2=Ronald |last3=Imani |first3=Farnad |date=2015-08-22 |title=Interventional Therapies for Chronic Low Back Pain: A Focused Review (Efficacy and Outcomes) |journal=Anesthesiology and Pain Medicine |volume=5 |issue=4 |pages=e29716 |doi=10.5812/aapm.29716 |pmc=4604560 |pmid=26484298}}</ref>
Once a person has had a [[psychological evaluation]] and deemed an appropriate candidate for SCS, a temporary implant is placed, called a trial, to determine the best stimulation pattern, and the person is sent home for three to ten days with an external pulse generator. If pain control and increased activity was achieved, a permanent system, with leads and a pulse generator, is placed.<ref name=Patel2015/>
== Contraindications ==
SCS may be contraindicated in people who have [[Coagulopathy|coagulation]] related disorders, or are on [[Anticoagulant|anticoagulant therapy.]]<ref name=Uptodate/> Other contraindications include local and systemic infection, [[pacemakers]], or those people for whom pre-surgical imaging studies show have anatomy that makes placement difficult, or if concerns arise during psychological evaluation.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Narouze |first=Samer |last2=Benzon |first2=Honorio T. |last3=Provenzano |first3=David A. |last4=Buvanendran |first4=Asokumar |last5=De Andres |first5=José |last6=Deer |first6=Timothy R. |last7=Rauck |first7=Richard |last8=Huntoon |first8=Marc A. |date=May 2015 |title=Interventional spine and pain procedures in patients on antiplatelet and anticoagulant medications: guidelines from the American Society of Regional Anesthesia and Pain Medicine, the European Society of Regional Anaesthesia and Pain Therapy, the American Academy of Pain Medicine, the International Neuromodulation Society, the North American Neuromodulation Society, and the World Institute of Pain |journal=Regional Anesthesia and Pain Medicine |volume=40 |issue=3 |pages=182–212 |doi=10.1097/AAP.0000000000000223 |pmid=25899949}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Deer |first=Timothy R. |last2=Mekhail |first2=Nagy |last3=Provenzano |first3=David |last4=Pope |first4=Jason |last5=Krames |first5=Elliot |last6=Leong |first6=Michael |last7=Levy |first7=Robert M. |last8=Abejon |first8=David |last9=Buchser |first9=Eric |date=August 2014 |title=The appropriate use of neurostimulation of the spinal cord and peripheral nervous system for the treatment of chronic pain and ischemic diseases: the Neuromodulation Appropriateness Consensus Committee |journal=Neuromodulation |volume=17 |issue=6 |pages=515–550; discussion 550 |doi=10.1111/ner.12208 |pmid=25112889}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Knezevic |first=Nebojsa N. |last2=Candido |first2=Kenneth D. |last3=Rana |first3=Shalini |last4=Knezevic |first4=Ivana |date=July 2015 |title=The Use of Spinal Cord Neuromodulation in the Management of HIV-Related Polyneuropathy |journal=Pain Physician |volume=18 |issue=4 |pages=E643–650 |pmid=26218955}}</ref>
==Adverse effects and complications== Complications with SCS range from simple easily correctable problems to devastating paralysis, nerve injury and death. In a 7-year follow-up, the overall complication rate was 5-18%. The most common complications include lead migration, lead breakage, and infection. Other complications include rotation of the pulse generator, [[haematoma]]s (subcutaneous or epidural), [[cerebrospinal fluid]] (CSF) leak, [[post dural puncture headache]], discomfort at pulse generator site, [[seroma]] and transient [[paraplegia]].<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Hayek |first=Salim M. |last2=Veizi |first2=Elias |last3=Hanes |first3=Michael |date=October 2015 |title=Treatment-Limiting Complications of Percutaneous Spinal Cord Stimulator Implants: A Review of Eight Years of Experience From an Academic Center Database |journal=Neuromodulation |volume=18 |issue=7 |pages=603–608; discussion 608–609 |doi=10.1111/ner.12312 |pmid=26053499}}</ref>
Some people find the tingling sensation caused by SPS to be unpleasant.<ref name=Deer2014/>
The most common hardware related complication is lead migration, in which the implanted electrodes move from their original placement. With this complication, recapturing paraesthesia coverage can be attempted with reprogramming.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Eldabe |first=Sam |last2=Buchser |first2=Eric |last3=Duarte |first3=Rui V. |date=2016-02-01 |title=Complications of Spinal Cord Stimulation and Peripheral Nerve Stimulation Techniques: A Review of the Literature |url=https://academic.oup.com/painmedicine/article/17/2/325/2460710/Complications-of-Spinal-Cord-Stimulation-and |journal=Pain Medicine |volume=17 |issue=2 |pages=325–336 |doi=10.1093/pm/pnv025}}</ref> In circumstances involving major lead migration a reoperation may be required to reset the lead placement.<ref name=Kumar2007>{{Cite journal |last=Kumar |first=Krishna |last2=Buchser |first2=Eric |last3=Linderoth |first3=Bengt |last4=Meglio |first4=Mario |last5=Van Buyten |first5=Jean-Pierre |date=January 2007 |title=Avoiding complications from spinal cord stimulation: practical recommendations from an international panel of experts |journal=Neuromodulation |volume=10 |issue=1 |pages=24–33 |doi=10.1111/j.1525-1403.2007.00084.x |pmid=22151809}}</ref> Studies differ greatly in reporting the percentage of people who have lead migration but the majority of studies report in the range of 10-25% of lead migration for spinal cord stimulation.<ref name=Kumar2007/>
==Mechanism of action== The neurophysiological mechanisms of action of spinal cord stimulation are not completely understood but may involve masking pain sensation with [[paresthesia |tingling]] by altering the pain processing of the [[central nervous system]].<ref name=Deer2014>{{Cite journal |last=Deer |first=Timothy R. |last2=Krames |first2=Elliot |last3=Mekhail |first3=Nagy |last4=Pope |first4=Jason |last5=Leong |first5=Michael |last6=Stanton-Hicks |first6=Michael |last7=Golovac |first7=Stan |last8=Kapural |first8=Leo |last9=Alo |first9=Ken |date=August 2014 |title=The appropriate use of neurostimulation: new and evolving neurostimulation therapies and applicable treatment for chronic pain and selected disease states. Neuromodulation Appropriateness Consensus Committee |journal=Neuromodulation |volume=17 |issue=6 |pages=599–615; discussion 615 |doi=10.1111/ner.12204 |pmid=25112892}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Sinclair |first=Chantelle |last2=Verrills |first2=Paul |last3=Barnard |first3=Adele |date=2016-07-01 |title=A review of spinal cord stimulation systems for chronic pain |journal=Journal of Pain Research |volume= 9 |pages=481–492 |doi=10.2147/jpr.s108884}}</ref> The mechanism of analgesia when SCS is applied in [[neuropathic]] pain states may be very different from that involved in analgesia due to limb ischemia.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Linderoth |first=B. |last2=Foreman |first2=R. D. |date=July 1999 |title=Physiology of spinal cord stimulation: review and update |journal=Neuromodulation |volume=2 |issue=3 |pages=150–164 |doi=10.1046/j.1525-1403.1999.00150.x |pmid=22151202}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Oakley |first=John C. |last2=Prager |first2=Joshua P. |date=2002-11-15 |title=Spinal cord stimulation: mechanisms of action |journal=Spine |volume=27 |issue=22 |pages=2574–2583 |doi= 10.1097/00007632-200211150-00034|pmid=12435996}}</ref> In neuropathic pain states, experimental evidence shows that SCS alters the local neurochemistry in dorsal horn, suppressing the hyperexcitability of the neurons. Specifically, there is some evidence for increased levels of [[GABA]] release, [[serotonin]], and perhaps suppression of levels of some excitatory amino acids, including [[glutamate]] and [[aspartate]]. In the case of ischemic pain, analgesia seems to derive from restoration of the oxygen demand supply. This effect could be mediated by inhibition of the [[sympathetic system]], although [[vasodilation]] is another possibility. It is also probable that a combination of the two above mentioned mechanisms is involved.<ref name="Kunnumourath">{{cite journal |last1=Kunnumpurath |first1=Sreekumar |last2=Srinivasagopalan |first2=Ravi |last3=Vadivelu |first3=Nalini |title=Spinal cord stimulation: principles of past, present and future practice: a review |journal=Journal of Clinical Monitoring and Computing |date=1 September 2009 |volume=23 |issue=5 |pages=333–339 |doi=10.1007/s10877-009-9201-0 |pmid=19728120}}</ref>
== History == Electrotherapy of pain by neurostimulation began shortly after Melzack and Wall proposed the [[Pain#Gate control|gate control theory]] in 1965. This theory proposed that nerves carrying painful peripheral stimuli and nerves carrying touch and vibratory sensation both terminate in the [[Posterior horn of spinal cord|dorsal horn]] (the gate) of spinal cord.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Kirkpatrick |first=Daniel R. |last2=McEntire |first2=Dan M. |last3=Hambsch |first3=Zakary J. |last4=Kerfeld |first4=Mitchell J. |last5=Smith |first5=Tyler A. |last6=Reisbig |first6=Mark D. |last7=Youngblood |first7=Charles F. |last8=Agrawal |first8=Devendra K. |date=December 2015 |title=Therapeutic Basis of Clinical Pain Modulation |journal=Clinical and Translational Science |volume=8 |issue=6 |pages=848–856 |doi=10.1111/cts.12282 |pmc=4641846 |pmid=25962969}}</ref> It was hypothesized that input to the latter could be manipulated to “close the gate” to the former. As an application of the gate control theory, Shealy et al.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Shealy |first=C. N. |last2=Mortimer |first2=J. T. |last3=Reswick |first3=J. B. |date=July 1967 |title=Electrical inhibition of pain by stimulation of the dorsal columns: preliminary clinical report |journal=Anesthesia and Analgesia |volume=46 |issue=4 |pages=489–491 |pmid=4952225 |doi=10.1213/00000539-196707000-00025}}</ref> implanted the first spinal cord stimulator device directly on the dorsal column for the treatment of chronic pain and in 1971, Shimogi and colleagues first reported the analgesic properties of epidural spinal cord stimulation. Since then this technique has undergone numerous technical and clinical developments.
At this time neurostimulation for the treatment of pain is used with [[nerve]] stimulation, spinal cord stimulation, [[deep brain stimulation]], and [[motor cortex]] stimulation.
== Research == SCS has been studied in people with Parkinson's disease<ref name=PD>{{Cite journal |last=de Andrade |first=Emerson Magno |last2=Ghilardi |first2=Maria Gabriela |last3=Cury |first3=Rubens Gisbert |last4=Barbosa |first4=Egberto Reis |last5=Fuentes |first5=Romulo |last6=Teixeira |first6=Manoel Jacobsen |last7=Fonoff |first7=Erich Talamoni |date=January 2016 |title=Spinal cord stimulation for Parkinson's disease: a systematic review |journal=Neurosurgical Review |volume=39 |issue=1 |pages=27–35; discussion 35 |doi=10.1007/s10143-015-0651-1 |pmid=26219854}}</ref> and [[angina pectoris]].<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Taylor |first=Rod S. |last2=De Vries |first2=Jessica |last3=Buchser |first3=Eric |last4=Dejongste |first4=Mike J. L. |date=2009-03-25 |title=Spinal cord stimulation in the treatment of refractory angina: systematic review and meta-analysis of randomised controlled trials |journal=BMC Cardiovascular Disorders |volume=9 |pages=13 |doi=10.1186/1471-2261-9-13 |pmc=2667170 |pmid=19320999}}</ref>
Research on improving the devices and software has included efforts to increasing the battery life, efforts to develop [[Feedback|closed loop]] control, and combining stimulation with implanted drug delivery systems.<ref name=PD/>
In August 2018, The European Commission's Horizon 2020 [[Future and Emerging Technologies]] program announced a $3.5 million funding grant for the four-nation project team that is building a prototype of an implant designed to 'rewire' the spinal cord.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.healthcareit.com.au/article/radical-project-aims-bridge-spinal-cord-injuries-and-give-patients-control-their-limbs|title=Radical project aims to bridge spinal cord injuries and give patients control of their limbs|date=2018-08-24|work=Healthcare IT Australia|access-date=2018-08-24|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.healthcareitnews.com/news/european-commission-funds-35-million-develop-prototype-implant-rewires-spinal-cord|title=European Commission funds $3.5 million to develop prototype implant that rewires a spinal cord|date=2018-08-23|work=Healthcare IT News|access-date=2018-08-24|language=en}}</ref>
In September 2018, the studied conducted by [[Mayo Clinic]] and [[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]] reported that spinal cord stimulation supported with physical therapy can help people with paralysis to regain their ability to stand and walk with assistance.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/09/180924115930.htm|title=Spinal cord stimulation, physical therapy help paralyzed man stand, walk with assistance|work=ScienceDaily|access-date=2018-09-25|language=en}}</ref>

{{DISPLAYTITLE:''Streptomyces'' isolates}} '''''Streptomyces'' isolates '''have yielded the majority of human, animal, and agricultural antibiotics, as well as a number of fundamental chemotherapy medicines. ''[[Streptomyces]]'' is the largest [[antibiotic]]-producing genus of [[actinobacteria]], producing chemotherapy, antibacterial, [[antifungal drug|antifungal]], antiparasitic drugs, and [[Immunosuppressive drug|immunosuppressants]].<ref name="pmid11702082">{{cite journal |vauthors=Watve MG, Tickoo R, Jog MM, Bhole BD |title=How many antibiotics are produced by the genus Streptomyces? |journal=Arch. Microbiol. |volume=176 |issue=5 |pages=386–90 |date=November 2001 |pmid=11702082 |doi=10.1007/s002030100345 |url=}}</ref> ''Streptomyces'' isolates are typically initiated with the aerial [[hyphal]] formation from the [[mycelium]]<ref name="Schrey-et-al-2012">{{cite journal | last1=Schrey | first1=Silvia D. | display-authors=etal | year=2012 | title=Production of fungal and bacterial growth modulating secondary metabolites is widespread among mycorrhiza-associated streptomycetes | url=https://bmcmicrobiol.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/1471-2180-12-164 | journal=BMC Microbiology | volume=12 | issue=1| pages=164 | doi=10.1186/1471-2180-12-164}}</ref>.
== Anticancer medicines == [[Image:Doxorubicin–DNA complex 1D12.png|thumb|150px|Doxorubicin [[Intercalation (chemistry)|intercalating DNA]].]]
''Streptomyces'', yielded the medicines [[doxorubicin]] ('''Doxil'''), [[daunorubicin]] ('''DaunoXome'''), and [[streptozotocin]] ('''Zanosar'''). Doxorubicin is the precursor to [[valrubicin]] ('''Valstar'''), [[myocet]], and [[pirarubicin]]. Daunorubicin is the precursor to [[idarubicin]] ('''Idamycin'''), [[epirubicin]] ('''Ellence'''), and [[zorubicin]].
''Streptomyces'' is the original source of [[dactinomycin]] ('''Cosmegen'''), [[bleomycin]] ('''Blenoxane'''), [[pingyangmycin]] ('''Bleomycin A<sub>5</sub>'''), [[mitomycin C]] ('''Mutamycin'''), [[rebeccamycin]], [[staurosporine]] (precursor to [[stauprimide]] and [[midostaurin]]), [[neothramycin]], [[aclarubicin]], tomaymycin, sibiromycin, and mazethramycin.
Derivatives of ''Streptomycetes'' isolate [[migrastatin]], including [[isomigrastatin]], dorrigocin A & B, and the synthetic derivative [[macroketone]], are being researched for anticancer activity.
== Antibiotics == Most clinical antibiotics were found during the "golden age of antibiotics" (1940s–1960s). [[Actinomycin]] was the first antibiotic isolated from ''Streptomyces'' in 1940, followed by [[streptomycin]] three years later. ''Streptomycetes'' isolates (including various [[aminoglycoside]]s) would go on to comprise over two-thirds of all marketed antibiotics.
''Streptomyces'' antibiotics include: {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[Chloramphenicol]] (''[[Streptomyces venezuelae]]'')<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1099/00221287-90-2-336|title=A Plasmid Involved in Chloramphenicol Production in Streptomyces venezuelae: Evidence from Genetic Mapping|year=1975|last1=Akagawa|first1=H.|last2=Okanishi|first2=M.|last3=Umezawa|first3=H.|journal=Journal of General Microbiology|volume=90|issue=2|pages=336–46|pmid=1194895}}</ref> * [[Daptomycin]] (''[[Streptomyces roseosporus]]'')<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1099/mic.0.27757-0|title=Daptomycin biosynthesis in Streptomyces roseosporus: Cloning and analysis of the gene cluster and revision of peptide stereochemistry|year=2005|last1=Miao|first1=V.|journal=Microbiology|volume=151|issue=5|pages=1507–23|pmid=15870461}}</ref> * [[Fosfomycin]] (''[[Streptomyces fradiae]]'')<ref name="pmid17113999">{{cite journal |vauthors=Woodyer RD, Shao Z, Thomas PM, etal |title=Heterologous production of fosfomycin and identification of the minimal biosynthetic gene cluster |journal=Chemistry & Biology |volume=13 |issue=11 |pages=1171–82 |date=November 2006 |pmid=17113999 |doi=10.1016/j.chembiol.2006.09.007 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1074-5521(06)00340-1}}</ref> * [[Lincomycin]] (''[[Streptomyces lincolnensis]]'')<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2958.1995.tb02338.x|title=Molecular characterization of the lincomycin-production gene cluster of Streptomyces lincolnensis 78-11|year=1995|last1=Peschke|first1=Ursula|last2=Schmidt|first2=Heike|last3=Zhang|first3=Hui-Zhan|last4=Piepersberg|first4=Wolfgang|journal=Molecular Microbiology|volume=16|issue=6|pages=1137–56|pmid=8577249}}</ref> * [[Neomycin]] (''[[Streptomyces fradiae]]'')<ref>{{cite journal|author=Howard T. Dulmage |title=The Production of Neomycin by Streptomyces fradiae in Synthetic Media |journal=Applied Microbiology |volume=1 |issue=2 |date=March 1953 |pages=103–106 |pmc=1056872 |pmid=13031516}}</ref> * [[Platensimycin]] (''[[Streptomyces platensis]]'') * [[Puromycin]] (''[[Streptomyces alboniger]]'')<ref>{{cite journal|author1=L. Sankaran |author2=Burton M. Pogell |lastauthoramp=yes |url=http://aac.asm.org/content/8/6/721.abstract |title=Biosynthesis of Puromycin in Streptomyces alboniger: Regulation and Properties of O-Demethylpuromycin O-Methyltransferase |journal=Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy |volume=8 |issue=6 |date=1975-12-01 |accessdate=2012-01-19|pmid=1211926|doi=10.1128/AAC.8.6.721|pages=721–32|pmc=429454}}</ref> * [[Streptomycin]] (''[[Streptomyces griseus]]'')<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1093/nar/15.19.8041|title=Gene cluster for streptomycin biosynthesis inStreptomyces griseus: Nucleotide sequence of three genes and analysis of transcriptional activity|year=1987|last1=Distler|first1=Jürgen|last2=Ebert|first2=Andrea|last3=Mansouri|first3=Kambiz|last4=Pissowotzki|first4=Klaus|last5=Stockmann|first5=Michael|last6=Piepersberg|first6=Wolfgang|journal=Nucleic Acids Research|volume=15|issue=19|pages=8041–56|pmid=3118332|pmc=306325}}</ref> * [[Tetracycline]] (''[[Streptomyces rimosus]]'' and ''[[Streptomyces aureofaciens]]'')<ref name="NelsonGreenwald2001">{{cite book|author1=Dr. Mark Nelson|author2=Robert A. Greenwald|author3=Wolfgang Hillen|author4=Mark L. Nelson|title=Tetracyclines in biology, chemistry and medicine|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kHNW4tFhZD4C&pg=PA8|accessdate=17 January 2012|year=2001|publisher=Birkhäuser|isbn=978-3-7643-6282-9|pages=8–}}</ref> }}
[[Clavulanic acid]] (''[[Streptomyces clavuligerus]]'') is used in combination with some antibiotics (like [[amoxicillin]]) to weaken bacterial-resistance. Novel antiinfectives being developed include [[Guadinomine]] (''Streptomyces'' sp. K01-0509),<ref name="Holmes2012">{{Cite journal|pmid= 23030602|year= 2012|last1= Holmes|first1= TC|last2= May|first2= AE|last3= Zaleta-Rivera|first3= K|last4= Ruby|first4= JG|last5= Skewes-Cox|first5= P|last6= Fischbach|first6= MA|last7= Derisi|first7= JL|last8= Iwatsuki|first8= M|last9= Ōmura|first9= S|last10= Khosla|first10= C|title= Molecular insights into the biosynthesis of guadinomine: A type III secretion system inhibitor|volume= 134|issue= 42|pages= 17797–806|doi= 10.1021/ja308622d|pmc= 3483642|journal= Journal of the American Chemical Society}}</ref> an inhibitor of the [[type III secretion system]].
Non-''Streptomyces'' [[actinomycetes]], filamentous [[fungi]], and non-filamentous [[bacteria]], have also yielded important antibiotics.
== Antifungals ==
[[Nystatin]] (''[[Streptomyces noursei]]''), [[amphotericin B]] (''[[Streptomyces nodosus]]''), and [[natamycin]] (''[[Streptomyces natalensis]]'') are antifungals isolated from ''Streptomyces''.
== Immunosuppressants == [[Sirolimus]] ('''Rapamycin'''), [[ascomycin]], and [[tacrolimus]] were isolated from ''Streptomyces''. [[Pimecrolimus]] is a derivative of ascomycin. [[Ubenimex]] is derived from ''S. olivoreticuli''.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Bauvois|first=B|author2=Dauzonne, D |title=Aminopeptidase-N/CD13 (EC 3.4.11.2) inhibitors: Chemistry, biological evaluations, and therapeutic prospects|journal=Medicinal Research Reviews|volume=26|issue=1|pages=88–130|doi=10.1002/med.20044|pmid=16216010|date=January 2006}}</ref>
== Antiparasitics == ''[[Streptomyces avermitilis]]'' synthesizes the antiparasitic [[ivermectin]] ('''Stromectol'''). Other antiparasitics made by ''Streptomyces'' include, [[milbemycin oxime]], [[moxidectin]], and [[milbemycin]].
== Biotechnology == [[File:Domain_organization_of_PKS_of_rapamycin_and_biosynthetic_intermediates.svg|thumb|Biosynthesis of [[sirolimus]]]] {{double image|right|Anthracycline aglycone biosyn1.png|97|E-rhod to doxorubicin biosynthesis222.png|100|[[Biosynthesis of doxorubicin]]||}} Traditionally, ''[[Escherichia coli]]'' is the choice bacterium to express [[Eukaryote|eukaryotic]] and [[Recombinant DNA|recombinant]] genes. ''E. coli'' is well understood and has a successful track record producing [[insulin]], the [[artemisinin]] precursor artemisinic acid, and [[filgrastim]] ('''Neupogen''').<ref name=Brawner_1991>{{cite journal |vauthors=Brawner M, Poste G, Rosenberg M, Westpheling J |title=''Streptomyces'': a host for heterologous gene expression |journal=Curr Opin Biotechnol |volume=2 |issue=5 |pages=674–81 |year=1991 |pmid=1367716 |doi=10.1016/0958-1669(91)90033-2}}</ref><ref name=Payne_1990>{{cite journal |vauthors=Payne G, DelaCruz N, Coppella S |title=Improved production of heterologous protein from ''Streptomyces lividans'' |journal=Appl Microbiol Biotechnol |volume=33 |issue=4 |pages=395–400 |year=1990 |pmid=1369282 |doi=10.1007/BF00176653}}</ref> However, use of ''E. coli'' has limitations including misfolding of eukaryotic proteins, insolubility issues, deposition in inclusion bodies, <ref name=Binnie_1997>{{cite journal |vauthors=Binnie C, Cossar J, Stewart D |title=Heterologous biopharmaceutical protein expression in ''Streptomyces'' |journal=Trends Biotechnol |volume=15 |issue=8 |pages=315–20 |year=1997 |pmid=9263479 |doi=10.1016/S0167-7799(97)01062-7}}</ref> low secretion efficiency, secretion to periplasmic space.
''Streptomyces'' offers potential advantages including superior secretion mechanisms, higher yields, a simpler end-product purification process, making ''Streptomyces'' an attractive alternative to ''E. coli'' and ''[[Bacillus subtilis]]''.<ref name="Binnie_1997"/>
''[[Streptomyces coelicolor]]'', ''[[Streptomyces avermitilis]]'', ''[[Streptomyces griseus]]'', and ''[[Saccharopolyspora erythraea]]'', are capable of secondary metabolite production. ''[[Streptomyces coelicolor]]'' has shown useful for the [[heterologous expression]] of proteins. Methods like "ribosome engineering" have been used to achieve 180-fold higher yields with ''S. coelicolor''.<ref name="pmid18310410">{{cite journal|vauthors=Wang G, Hosaka T, Ochi K | title=Dramatic activation of antibiotic production in Streptomyces coelicolor by cumulative drug resistance mutations. | journal=Appl Environ Microbiol | year= 2008 | volume= 74 | issue= 9 | pages= 2834–40 | pmid=18310410 | doi=10.1128/AEM.02800-07 | pmc=2394871 }}</ref>
== Other == StreptomeDB, a directory of ''Streptomyces'' isolates, contains over 2400 compounds isolated from more than 1900 strains.<ref name="pmid23193280">{{cite journal |vauthors=Lucas X, Senger C, Erxleben A, Grüning BA, Döring K, Mosch J, etal | title=StreptomeDB: a resource for natural compounds isolated from Streptomyces species. | journal=Nucleic Acids Res | year= 2013 | volume= 41 | issue= Database issue | pages= D1130-6 | pmid=23193280 | doi=10.1093/nar/gks1253 | pmc=3531085 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.pharmaceutical-bioinformatics.de/streptomedb/compound_list/]</ref> ''[[Streptomyces hygroscopicus]]'' and ''[[Streptomyces viridochromeogenes]]'' produce the herbicide [[bialaphos]]. Expansion of ''Streptomyces'' screenings have included [[endophytes]], [[extremophiles]], and [[Marine biology|marine]] varieties.
A recent screening of [[Traditional Chinese medicine|TCM]] extracts revealed a ''Streptomyces'' that produces a number of antitubercular [[pluramycin A|pluramycin]]s.<ref name="pmid24190497">{{cite journal |vauthors=Liu M, Abdel-Mageed WM, Ren B, He W, Huang P, Li X, etal | title=Endophytic Streptomyces sp. Y3111 from traditional Chinese medicine produced antitubercular pluramycins. | journal=Appl Microbiol Biotechnol | year= 2014 | volume= 98 | issue= 3 | pages= 1077–85 | doi=10.1007/s00253-013-5335-6 | pmc= | pmid=24190497 }}</ref>

Player of the Year | year1 = 2006, 2009 | award2 = | year2 = | awardssection = }} '''Ted Potter Jr. '''(born November 9, 1983) is an American [[professional golfer]] who plays on the [[PGA Tour]]. He is a left-handed golfer, but is naturally right-handed. He is a two-time winner on the PGA Tour, having also won twice on the [[Web.com Tour]]. He is often described as a career journeyman golfer and mini-tour legend, due to his dominance of numerous minor league golfing tours. ==Early life== Potter was born in [[Ocala, Florida]], and resided the majority of his childhood in nearby [[Silver Springs, Florida|Silver Springs]].{{cite web |title=Ted Potter, Jr. Profile |url=http://www.pgatour.com/players/02/75/56/ |publisher=PGA Tour |accessdate=April 4, 2011}} He is the son of Ted Potter Sr. and Dale Potter. His father is a retired a golf course maintenance professional who worked at Silver Springs Shores Country Club and various other Ocala area courses. His mother currently still works for [[Walmart]] as a Department Manager.{{cite magazine |url=http://golfweek.com/2012/07/08/ted-potter-jr-shows-his-power-perservere/ |title=Potter Jr. shows his power to persevere |magazine=Golfweek |date=July 8, 2012}} He began to play golf at a very early age. His father made him a custom set of clubs as soon as he could grip a golf club and was his chief instructor of the game.{{cite web |last=Marks |first=Andy |title=Marion County's Potter on golf's biggest stage |url=http://preps.ocala.com/news/article/29283/marion-countys-potter-on-golfs-biggest-stage/?pa=1&tc=pg |date=January 12, 2012 |website=Ocala.com |accessdate=August 9, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120715024657/http://preps.ocala.com/news/article/29283/marion-countys-potter-on-golfs-biggest-stage/?pa=1&tc=pg |archivedate=July 15, 2012 |df= }} Potter would go on to dominate Florida youth golfing tours winning numerous youth events. His success continued through his high school career. He won all-district honors three times in high school. He graduated in 2002 from [[Lake Weir High School]] in southeastern [[Marion County, Florida|Marion County]], and chose to turn pro instead of attending college. ==Professional career== ===Mini-tours career=== Potter turned pro at the age of 19 where he first competed on the Central Florida-based Moonlight Tour. He supplemented his income working in the cart barn at Lake Diamond Golf & Country Club in Ocala, Florida.{{cite news |last=Elling |first=Steve |title=Long Shot Takes Best Shot At PGA |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2003-12-03/sports/0312030404_1_ted-potter-antithesis-magee |newspaper=Orlando Sentinel |date=December 3, 2003 |accessdate=April 9, 2011}}{{cite news |url=http://espn.go.com/golf/notebook/_/page/weekly18110213/jason-sobel-weekly-18 |last=Sobel |first=Jason |title=Jason Sobel's Weekly 18 (#4 Ted Potter, Jr.) |work=ESPN |date=February 13, 2011 |accessdate=April 9, 2011}} Potter is estimated to have over 60 mini-tour victories at various levels of mini-tour competition.{{cite web |title= Unheralded golfer Ted Potter Jr. wins at Pebble Beach |url=https://www.sfgate.com/sports/golf/article/Unheralded-golfer-Ted-Potter-Jr-wins-at-Pebble-12605857.php/ |website=SFGate.com |accessdate=February 8, 2018 |first=Ron |last=Kroichick |date=February 11, 2018}} Potter was the 2006 and 2009 [[NGA Hooters Tour]] Player of the Year.{{cite web |title=2009 Season Wrap Up |url=http://www.ngatour.com/general/news/release_355.html |publisher=NGA Hooters Tour |accessdate=April 9, 2011}}{{cite web |title=NGA Hooters Tour Begins 2010 Season At Golden Hills |url=http://www.ngatour.com/general/news/release_429.html |publisher=NGA Tour |accessdate=April 9, 2011}} He has a total of seven regular season wins and five winter series victories on the NGA Tour. He is currently tied for third place all-time in wins.{{cite web |title=Ted Potter wins NGA/Hooters Tour Bridgestone Winter Series event at Forest Lake Golf Club |url=http://www.golfblogger.co.uk/post/ted-potter-wins-ngahooters-tour-bridgestone-winter-series-event-at-forest-lake-golf-club-eb4 |publisher=golfblogger.co.uk |date=February 11, 2011 |accessdate=April 9, 2011}}{{cite web |title=Hooters Tour Career Wins |url=http://www.ngatour.com/general/career_wins.html |publisher=NGA Tour |accessdate=April 4, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707143702/http://www.ngatour.com/general/career_wins.html |archivedate=July 7, 2011 |df= }}{{cite web |title=Ted Potter Wins at Sugarloaf Mountain |url=http://www.ngatour.com/general/news/release_681.html |publisher=NGA Tour |accessdate=April 9, 2011}} His career winnings on the NGA tour are $595,490.72 (623,000 including winter series events).{{cite web |last=Marks |first=Andy |title=Ocala golfer Ted Potter dominates on Hooters Tour |url=http://www.ocala.com/article/20090624/articles/906241009 |website=Ocala.com |date=June 24, 2009 |accessdate=August 9, 2012}}{{cite web |title=Ted Potter, Jr: Player Stats |url=http://www.ngahooters.tourgolfscores.com/public/standings/player_stats.cfm?pcid=818&yearID=&tid= |publisher=NGA Tour |accessdate=April 4, 2011}} ===2003–2011: Nationwide Tour career=== In December 2003, he competed for a spot on the PGA Tour via the 2003 [[PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament]]. He finished tied for 74th place{{cite news |title=Scores-PGA Tour Q-School 2003 |url=http://www.thegolfchannel.com/pga-tour/2003-pga-tour-q-school/scores/ |work=The Golf Channel |accessdate=April 9, 2011}}{{dead link|date=February 2018}} and earned a spot on the 2004 [[Nationwide Tour]] (former name of the Web.com Tour), where he did not make a single cut during the season.{{cite news |title=Lesson Learned From Q-School |url=http://www.thegolfchannel.com/tour-insider/lessons-learned-at-q-school-11618/ |work=The Golf Channel |accessdate=April 9, 2011}}{{dead link|date=February 2018}} Potter again competed on the Nationwide Tour during the 2007 season with little success.{{cite web |last=Marks |first=Andy |title=Potter returns to Nationwide Tour |url=http://www.ocala.com/article/20100623/sports/100629898 |website=Ocala.com |date=June 24, 2010 |accessdate=April 9, 2011}}{{cite magazine |title=Q-School:Second-Stage Recap |url=http://www.golfweek.com/news/2009/nov/21/q-school-williamson-proud-second-stage-success/ |magazine=GolfWeek |date=November 22, 2009 |accessdate=April 9, 2011}}{{cite web |last=Saucer |first=Byron |title=Potter cashes in on Nationwide Tour |url=http://www.ocala.com/article/20101013/sports/101019905 |website=Ocala.com |date=October 13, 2010 |accessdate=April 9, 2011}} He made his first cut on the Nationwide Tour at the 2007 [[Movistar Panama Championship]] where he finished tied for 12th place.{{cite web |title=Ted Potter, Jr. – 2007 Results |url=https://www.pgatour.com/players/player.27556.ted-potter--jr-.html |publisher=PGA Tour |accessdate=February 13, 2018}}{{cite web |last=Lagarde |first=Dave |title=The grass is looking greener for Potter |url=http://www.pgatour.com/2007/h/02/27/lagarde_potter/index.html |publisher=PGA Tour |accessdate=April 9, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070302104557/http://www.pgatour.com/2007/h/02/27/lagarde_potter/index.html |archivedate=March 2, 2007}}{{cite web |title=Nationwide Tour heading back Down Under |url=http://www.pgatour.com/2007/h/02/14/jacobs_open_advance/index.html |publisher=PGA Tour |first=Maureen |last=Callaghan |date=February 15, 2007 |accessdate=April 9, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071101035538/http://www.pgatour.com/2007/h/02/14/jacobs_open_advance/index.html |archivedate=November 1, 2007}} Overall, he entered 20 events during the 2007 season making only three cuts for earning a total of $16,014 finishing in 189th place. He did not regain his Nationwide Tour card and returned to mini-tour competition for 2008 and 2009. Potter regained his Nationwide Tour card again in 2010. He entered 11 events making only three cuts and finished in 148th place. He did not regain his Nationwide Tour card and returned to mini-tour competition again for the start of 2011. The 2011 season was Potter's breakout as a professional golfer. He started the season on the NGA Tour, but won the [[South Georgia Classic]] on what was then the Nationwide Tour, the first time a [[Monday qualifier]] won on the tour since 2006. Prior to winning the South Georgia Classic, Potter made six cuts in 55 [[Web.com Tour]] events. He was only the fifth left-handed golfer to win an event on the tour and the first since 2008. The win earned Potter $112,500 and full Nationwide Tour status for 2011.{{cite web |url=http://www.pgatour.com/2011/tournaments/h092/05/01/Rd4-wrapup/index.html |title=Monday qualifier Potter Jr. wins |url=http://www.pga.com/news/nationwide-tour/left-hander-ted-potter-wins-nationwide-soboba-golf-classic-in-sudden-death |publisher=PGA of America |date=September 26, 2011 |accessdate=August 9, 2012}} Potter finished in the top 25 (2nd place overall) in earnings on the tour in 2011 and earned his PGA Tour card for the 2012 season.{{cite magazine |last=Martin |first=Sean |title=2011 Year in review: Top 10 Nationwide stories |url=http://mobile.golfweek.com/news/2011/dec/21/2011-review-top-10-nationwide-stories/ |accessdate=August 9, 2012 |magazine=Golfweek |date=December 21, 2011}} Overall, he entered 18 Nationwide Tour events in 2011 making the cut 12 times with six finishes in the top-10. ===2012: PGA Tour rookie season and maiden win=== Potter made his PGA Tour debut at the [[Sony Open in Hawaii]] in January 2012, where he finished in a tie for 13th.{{cite magazine |last=Martin |first=Sean |title=PGA Tour rookie Potter perseveres |url=http://golfweek.com/news/2012/jan/16/pga-tour-rookie-potter-perseveres/ |accessdate=August 9, 2012 |magazine=Golfweek |date=January 16, 2012}} He achieved his first PGA Tour win at the [[Greenbrier Classic]] on July 8 of that year, after having missed the previous five cuts.{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/golf/top-stories/Potter-beats-Kelly-in-playoff-to-win-Greenbrier-Classic/articleshow/14759245.cms |title=Potter beats Kelly in playoff to win Greenbrier Classic |newspaper=[[The Times of India]] |agency=Associated Press |date=July 9, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120712063634/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com//sports/golf/top-stories/Potter-beats-Kelly-in-playoff-to-win-Greenbrier-Classic/articleshow/14759245.cms |archivedate=July 12, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Potter trailed [[Troy Kelly]] by several strokes but shot −4 on the last four holes to force a playoff. Potter, ranked number 218 in the [[Official World Golf Ranking]] at the time, went on to win the playoff on the third extra hole, after missing a birdie putt to win on the second extra hole. Potter was 173rd in the [[FedEx Cup]] before the win, which vaulted him to 51st in the FedEx Cup and 83rd in the world. He also qualified for the [[2012 Open Championship]], his first major championship appearance, as a result of winning the tournament. He also earned a two-year exemption for winning, plus invitations to the [[2012 PGA Championship]], 2012 [[Bridgestone Invitational]], and 2013 [[Masters Tournament]].{{cite magazine |last=Micelli |first=Alex |title=Potter, Kelly, Hicks play strong at Open Championship |url=http://golfweek.com/news/2012/jul/20/potter-kelly-hicks-play-strong-open-championship/ |magazine=Golfweek |date=July 20, 2012}}{{cite news |last=Marks |first=Andy |title=Exclusive Bridgestone event to include Potter |url=http://www.ocala.com/article/20120731/SPORTS/120739940 |website=Ocala.com |date=July 31, 2012}} Potter made his debut in a major championship at the 2012 Open Championship where he finished in a tie for 60th place. For the season, he finished with 652 FedEx Cup points (93rd place) and second in voting for PGA Tour Rookie of the Year. ===2013–2016: PGA Tour and ankle injury=== Potter capped off a successful rookie campaign with a solid second season on tour. During the 2013 season, Potter entered 22 events and made 11 cuts including two top-10 finishes and five top-25 finishes. He earned 518 FedEx Cup points finishing in 105th place and had $829,770 in earnings for the season. His best performance of the 2013 season was at the Greenbrier Classic were finished in 6th place with a score of 271 (−9). Potter struggled during the 2014 season missing the cut in 15 of 24 events entered earning a total of $386,341. He had three top-25 finishes. Potter's season ended with an off-course ankle injury while at a hotel during the [[RBC Canadian Open]]. Potter broke his ankle in July 2014 and did not play again until April 2016. After making his five allotted Web.com Tour rehab starts, he tried to regain PGA Tour privileges with the last two starts of his major medical extension. ===2016–2017: Return to Web.com Tour=== After failing to meet the terms of his medical extension, he returned to the Web.com Tour for the remainder of the 2016 season, where he finished 50th on the money list. He entered 14 tournaments and made 12 cuts. He regained his Web.com Tour card for the following season. With only past champion status on the PGA Tour during the 2017 season, Potter spent much of the 2017 season on the Web.com Tour. During the 2017 season, Potter entered 22 tournaments making the cut a total of 15 times including six top-10 finishes. His best finishes during his 2017 campaign include a second place finish at the [[Rust-Oleum Championship]] and another second place finish (tie) at the [[Albertsons Boise Open]]. Potter finished in the top-25 (14th overall) on the Web.com Tour and re-earned full status for the 2018 season. He qualified for the [[2017 U.S. Open (golf)|2017 U.S. Open]] where he failed to make the cut and entered the PGA Tour's 2017 [[Greenbrier Classic]] as a past champion where he finished in a tie for 37th place. ===2017–2018: Return to PGA Tour=== Potter began the 2017–18 season missing five of the first eight cuts of the season. In February 2018, Potter won his second PGA Tour title at the [[AT&T Pebble Beach Pro-Am]] with a three-shot victory over [[Dustin Johnson]], [[Jason Day]], [[Phil Mickelson]], and [[Chez Reavie]], earning a two-year PGA Tour exemption through 2019–20 season and invitations to the [[2018 Masters Tournament]] and [[2018 PGA Championship]].{{cite news |url=http://www.espn.com/golf/story/_/id/22402848/ted-potter-jr-outplays-dustin-johnson-win-att-pebble-beach-national |title=Ted Potter Jr. outplays Dustin Johnson and wins Pebble Beach |work=ESPN |agency=Associated Press |date=February 12, 2018}} During the third round of the tournament, he shot his personal best score of 62 on the PGA Tour. The win catapulted him from 243 to a career-best 73 in the Official World Golf Ranking. ==Personal life== Potter currently resides in Silver Springs, Florida, with his wife Cheri Renee Potter. He has one son Corbin who was born in 2016.{{cite magazine |title= Poised Ted Potter Jr. earns second Tour win at AT&T Pebble Beach Pro-Am |url=http://golfweek.com/2018/02/11/ted-potter-jr-ends-pga-tour-drought-with-win-at-pebble-beach/ |magazine=Golfweek |date=February 11, 2018 |first=Brentley |last=Romine}} He has one sibling, Stephanie Potter. He is an avid fisherman and hunter. ==Professional wins (19+)== ===PGA Tour wins (2)=== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:95%;" !No.!!Date!!Tournament!!Winning score!!Margin of

[[Shapiro-Glickenhaus Entertainment]] (Non-US) | released = {{Film date|1988|11|04}} | runtime = 94 minutes | country = Canada | language = English }} '''''The Brain''''' is a 1988 Canadian [[Science fiction film|science fiction]] [[horror film]] depicting a giant [[brain]]-like [[Extraterrestrial life in fiction|alien]] that terrorizes. The film has developed a small cult following.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/37913/habermans-retrospective-hijinx-pick-your-poison|title=Haberman's Retrospective Hijinx - Pick Your Poison!|publisher=DreadCentral}} ==Plot== Dr. Blakely runs a TV show called ''Independent Thinkers'', which is a Scientology-like self-help/religion program. But he's not making his audience think any more independently - with the help of an alien organism he calls The Brain, he's using brainwashing and mind control. The only thing that stands between them and world domination is a brilliant but troubled high school student with a penchant for pranks. ==Cast== {{Cast listing| *[[David Gale (actor)|David Gale]] as Dr. Anthony Blakely *Tom Bresnahan as Jim Majelewski *[[Cynthia Preston]] as Janet *[[George Buza]] as Varna *Brett Pearson as Willie *Sarah Chapple as Debbie Hodges *Christine Kossak as Vivian }} ==Release== The movie was released on [[VHS|videocassette]] and [[laserdisc]] in 1989 by [[International Video Entertainment]].{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0094794/companycredits|title=Company Credits for The Brain|publisher=imdb.com|accessdate=2011-04-18}} The movie was officially released on DVD in the UK in late 2011 by Boulevard Entertainment, but has since gone out of print. ==Other versions== The movie was riffed during the [[Mystery Science Theater 3000]] LIVE tour of 2018. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote}} *{{IMDb title|0094794|The Brain}} * {{Amg movie|6911|The Brain}} * {{tcmdb title|69556}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Brain, The}} [[Category:1988 horror films]] [[Category:1988 films]] [[Category:Canadian films]] [[Category:Canadian horror films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Fictional amorphous creatures]] [[Category:Fictional body parts]] [[Category:Films scored by Paul Zaza]] [[Category:Giant monster films]] [[Category:Canadian science fiction films]] [[Category:1980s science fiction films]] [[Category:1980s science fiction horror films]] [[Category:Alien invasions in films]] {{sf-horror-film-stub}}

{{Orphan|date=December 2015}} {{Correct title|title=#WhyIStayed/#WhyILeft|reason=#}}
'''<nowiki>#</nowiki>WhyIStayed''' became a trending hashtag in November 2014 in defense of [[Domestic Violence|domestic abuse]] victims after a media release of security camera footage that appeared to show [[NFL]] player, [[Ray Rice#Domestic Violence|Ray Rice]], punching his then-fiancee, Janay Rice, sparked public conversation on why Janay and other victims of abuse choose to stay in abusive relationships. The [[hashtag]] was started by writer and domestic abuse survivor [[Beverly Gooden]] via [[Twitter]] in an effort to "change the tone of the conversation."<ref name="CNN">{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2014/09/09/living/rice-video-why-i-stayed/|title=Meredith Vieira Explains #WhyIStayed|website=cnn.com|last1=Grinberg|first1=Emanuella|accessdate=9 December 2014}}</ref> It began to trend nationally five hours after its creation<ref name="Today">{{cite web|url=http://www.today.com/news/beyond-ray-rice-whyistayed-hashtag-personalizes-domestic-violence-1D80137572|title=Beyond Ray Rice: #WhyIStayed personalizes domestic violence|website=today.com|last1=Serico|first1=Chris|accessdate=12 December 2014}}</ref> and was used more than 46,000 times that day, according to the Web analytics tool, [[Topsy (analytics)|Topsy]].<ref name="USA Today">{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2014/09/10/why-i-stayed-hashtag-twitter-ray-rice/15385027/|title=#WhyIStayed: Powerful Stories of Domestic Violence|website=usatoday.com|last1=Lee|first1=Jolie|accessdate=12 December 2014}}</ref> '''#WhyILeft''' was a later addition to the Twitter conversation.
== Background == Beverly Gooden's rationale for staying with her husband was that it was step one in her move to eventually leave her abusive relationship; Janay Rice, on the other hand, expressed that she has no intention of divorcing her now-husband and does not view herself as an abuse victim.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/11913473/janay-rice-gives-own-account-night-atlantic-city|title=Janay Rice, in her own words|work=ESPN.com|access-date=2017-04-05}}</ref> In the wake of media attention after the release of the tape, Janay came out in support of Ray on [[Instagram]], writing, "To make us relive a moment in our lives that we regret every day is a horrible thing."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/3308901/janay-rice-ray-rice-nfl-baltimore-ravens/|title=Janay Rice Instagrams a statement defending her husband and criticizing the media and NFL|website=Time|access-date=2017-04-05}}</ref>
Beyond the pull to stay together for the sake of their daughter, Rayven, Janay argued that the violent night in [[Atlantic City]] was an anomaly in their relationship. In an interview with [[ESPN]], she said, "As angry as I was, I knew it was something that we could move on from because I know Ray."<ref name=":0" /> She added that the violence was not one-sided; Janay was the one to initiate it, slapping Ray before he assaulted her.<ref name=":0" /> She stressed that she hopes people can see the love that the two have for one another despite one isolated incident, and how much they have grown because of it.
On November 8, 2014, creator [[Beverly Gooden]] posted the following message to her website to elaborate on her inspiration for #WhyIStayed:
"The internet exploded with questions about [Janay Rice] … why didn't she leave? Why did she marry him? Why did she stay? I can't speak for Janay Rice, but I can speak for Beverly Gooden. Why did I stay? … Leaving was a process, not an event. And sometimes it takes a while to navigate through the process. I believe in storytelling. I believe in the power of shared experience. I believe that we find strength in community. That is why I created this hashtag. I hope those tweeting using #WhyIStayed find a voice, find love, find compassion, and find hope."<ref name="Today" />
Stories of why victims stayed varied from feeling unable to leave out of fear to not knowing that abuse was abnormal. Victims left because they realized their lives were in jeopardy, they started to believe they deserved better, and/or they wanted to protect their children.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ajc.com/news/national/domestic-abuse-the-spotlight-with-whyistayed-and-whyileft-hashtag-campaigns/EPLRCWUFgJ4XEZD4DQUn6M/|title=Domestic abuse in the spotlight with #WhyIStayed and #WhyILeft...|last=Desk|first=Cox Media Group National Content|website=ajc|access-date=2017-04-05}}</ref>
== Response == In response to #WhyIStayed/#WhyIleft, Janay said she was thankful that her experience with domestic violence instigated the movement. Despite the difficulty of enduring the scrutiny that comes from the publicization of a private moment, Janay said that the fact that it began a conversation about abuse was a silver lining.<ref name=":0" />
The hashtag gained significant attention from national media, as well as from the [[National Domestic Violence Hotline]] via Twitter. The organization thanked all who were sharing their stories with #WhyIStayed and informed users about their services.<ref name="Today" />
== Misuse of the hashtag == After #WhyIStayed became a trending topic on [[Twitter]], it was mistakenly used by the [[DiGiorno|DiGiorno's Pizza]] Twitter handle as a marketing effort. They tweeted, "#WhyIStayed You had pizza."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://abc7chicago.com/sports/twitter-backlash-when-digiorno-uses-whyistayed-to-sell-pizzas-after-ray-rice-scandal/301149/|title=Twitter backlash when DiGiorno uses #WhyIStayed to sell pizzas after Ray Rice scandal|date=2014-09-09|work=ABC7 Chicago|access-date=2017-04-05|language=en-US}}</ref> The administrator for the account later removed the tweet and apologized for the mistake, claiming that no one had looked into the implication of the trending hashtag before taking to Twitter. While many Twitter users brushed over the error, others were deeply angered as they believed DiGiorno was making light of an incredibly serious topic. In response, DiGiorno answered every negative tweet with personal messages conveying their apologies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/katrina-sands/a-lesson-in-crisis-commun_b_5794122.html|title=A Lesson in Crisis Communications, Courtesy of DiGiorno|last=Sands|first=Katrina|date=2014-09-10|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2017-04-05}}</ref> DiGiorno has since removed the original tweet—but not before screenshots were taken to verify the event.<ref name="Time">{{cite web|url=http://time.com/3308861/digiorno-social-media-pizza/|title=DiGiorno Used a Hashtag About Domestic Violence to Sell Pizza|website=time.com|last1=Stampler|first1=Laura|accessdate=9 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="Washington Post">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/compost/wp/2014/09/09/whyistayed-digiorno-and-other-corporate-disasters/|title=#WhyIStayed, DiGiorno, and Other Corporate Disasters|website=washingtonpost.com|last1=Petri|first1=Alexandra|accessdate=12 December 2014}}</ref>
==References== <references />
